story:
We have completed 5 locations that are available to ship before Christmas!

Dallas was the first city built. It's our hometown. After Dallas we began accepting votes and quickly expanded to other Texas cities such as Fort Worth and Houston. We've since expanded out to Los Angeles with more on the way!

Chicago and San Francisco have the highest vote counts so we're currently working on the plot for Chicago and expect to be done shortly after this campaign. San Francisco will follow shortly after Chicago.

We estimate that we can complete a new city every 6 weeks. 

Where would you like to go? You can place a single vote for free on our website right now!

 

We're offering a limited edition stainless steel infused version of each skyline. Yes, you heard that right. Powderized stainless steel is infused in the plastic prior to being 3D printed. The effect is added weight and a really cool cast metal look.

These are really cool, but the material cost is over 10X as expensive as the white plastic so we're only offering a limited quantity.

 

.

3D Printed Skylines started out as a hobby project to map a to-scale model of downtown Dallas and then bring it to life through 3D printing. The original print was intended to be a decorative reminder of Dallas that Brandon could place on his desk to appreciate.

It was then used as a prize for a fun game played at a housewarming party for a new Dallas resident and friend. The 3D printer worked on the model during the party and people could guess what was printing. The first guesses were pretty hysterical but eventually someone guessed Dallas. They got to take it home that night!

Word soon got out. D Magazine wrote this article and people began asking if other cities could be made. A survey to collect votes was put up on a website and 3D Printed Skylines was born.

.

 

.

PLA (polylactic acid) is one of the best materials to create objects with a 3D printer. It is a bioplastic made from a number of plant products including corn, potatoes and sugar-beets. PLA is considered an 'earth friendly' plastic that is environmentally friendly and can be composted at commercial compost facilities. PLA can easily be painted with cellulose spray paints and oil paints, although acrylic paints are considered the best choice. 

Stainless Steel PLA is a compound of PLA and finely ground, powderized stainless steel. It has the same natural properties as PLA in addition to being a highly dense material that looks like cast metal. Due to the addition of steel, this model carries more weight than the Bright White PLA.

Walnut is a hardwood with beautiful grain patterns. It is popular in high end furniture and a preferred species for architectural millwork. It is also used for cabinetry, gunstocks, turnings and much more.

The walnut bases are coated with a protective sealer made from a mixture of boiled linseed oil, pure tung oil and polyurethane oil. This mixture really brings out the grain pattern by building contrast between the lighter and darker colors.

This is a to-scale model of downtown Dallas. The boundaries are set from the corner of Griffin and Young St, up to Hord St, & down Crockett St.

This metal infused plastic version of the Dallas skyline is looking really great. Here is a picture to get an idea of size in real life. p.s. those books are pretty big.

This is a to-scale model of downtown Los Angeles. The boundaries are set by the roads, Fremont Ave, W 3rdSt, Hill St, and W 8th St.

Perspective shot of the LA skyline to get a feel for size in real life. It is sitting on a large coffee table in front of a plaid couch.

This is a to-scale model of downtown Houston. The boundaries are set by the roads, Bagby St, Texas Ave, Austin St, and Clay St.

This is a to-scale model of downtown Houston. The boundaries are set by the roads, Bagby St, Texas Ave, Austin St, and Clay St.

This is a to-scale model of downtown Fort Worth. The boundaries are set by the roads, W Belknap St, Jones St, W 7th St, and Bernett St.

This is a to-scale model of the Texas State Capitol building located in Austin, TX. The building stands 308ft tall; it is 2.64in in this model (67mm).

Backside view of the Texas State Capitol.

Video production - Brett A Vance

Audio - Derek from sixfigurecrowdfunding.com

Video Set - Common Desk

3D Printers - MakerGear 3D Printers

Filament - ProtoPlan Proto-pasta

.

Risks & Challenges

3D Printers are very technical machines with moving parts. It is normal to have a part malfunction and require replacement from time to time. We have attempted to include these unforeseen replacements into our production capacity calculations so that we can ensure delivery by January. Of course, if things were to go worse than expected it is possible that we will not be able to deliver every single order before January, 2018. Luckily, we can always purchase more 3D printers to increase our capacity and will be ready to do so.

If our current lumber supplier shuts down then we will have to purchase wood from another supplier. Switching suppliers could affect our production timeline. Luckily, the lumber yard is located in a wood and granite district with other lumber suppliers close by so it should not take much time to switch suppliers.

Shipping times can be a bit unreliable around the holidays. Our production projections include a multiple-day buffer in the days leading up to Christmas to ensure that orders are delivered in time, but we cannot guarantee that a shipping company will not take longer than projected to ship your reward to you.

The boundaries are set by the roads, Bagby St, Texas Ave, Austin St, and Clay St.This is a to-scale model of downtown Houston. The boundaries are set by the roads, Bagby St, Texas Ave, Austin St, and Clay St.This is a to-scale model of downtown Fort Worth. The boundaries are set by the roads, W Belknap St, Jones St, W 7th St, and Bernett St.This is a to-scale model of the Texas State Capitol building located in Austin, TX. The building stands 308ft tall; it is 2.64in in this model (67mm).Backside view of the Texas State Capitol.Video production - Brett A VanceAudio - Derek from sixfigurecrowdfunding.comVideo Set - Common Desk3D Printers - MakerGear 3D PrintersFilament - ProtoPlan Proto-pasta.Risks & Challenges3D Printers are very technical machines with moving parts. It is normal to have a part malfunction and require replacement from time to time. We have attempted to include these unforeseen replacements into our production capacity calculations so that we can ensure delivery by January. Of course, if things were to go worse than expected it is possible that we will not be able to deliver every single order before January, 2018. Luckily, we can always purchase more 3D printers to increase our capacity and will be ready to do so.If our current lumber supplier shuts down then we will have to purchase wood from another supplier. Switching suppliers could affect our production timeline. Luckily, the lumber yard is located in a wood and granite district with other lumber suppliers close by so it should not take much time to switch suppliers.Shipping times can be a bit unreliable around the holidays. Our production projections include a multiple-day buffer in the days leading up to Christmas to ensure that orders are delivered in time, but we cannot guarantee that a shipping company will not take longer than projected to ship your reward to you.

story:
My mom suffers from a cancer, it killed her left thyroid and she had to get 90% of her right thyroid removed,  this campaign is to help her raise money to help with her surgery, and spread awareness to both men and women. That is her wish, and I am trying to fulfill it.

We can spend $7 on a cup of coffee from Starbucks, $5 on a pack of cigarettes, but when it comes to the things that truly matter, we wont spend a dime. 

It's through the selfishness of people that awareness isn't as knowledgeable as it should be, and I hope to help change this through something we can visually perceive and connect with. The Power of Art, and words.

Please help spread the word, share a link to this campaign, or make a small pledge. It's through your actions that makes awareness spread.

The Campaign: Power of Art

Most art has the power to invoke thought, emotions, but most of all, drive and passion. I hope to share stories through art to promote breast cancer awareness, and help people see and realize how important awareness is. Many do not have awareness, nor those who can truly point it out, and help inspire. 

  • Symbolism through art to promote awarness.
  • Give the gift of a beautiful work of art.
  • Raise funds to help those in need, and contribute to other campaigns.

Remember, the power of art and the lives that can be helped due to it. 25% of funds raised above my goal, will go to any Breast Cancer Awareness charity you the people choose and make comment about.

Breast Cancer Artwork and Stories:

Name: Harmony


The story behind Harmony is one of struggle, the strugle to maintain beauty. There are five petals on the flower, depicting the five stages of Breast cancer, and as each stage passes, and a struggle in life has come, a petal falls. A symbol that it shall never be whole again though still remaining beautiful.

 

Name: Emergence

Emergence symbolizes those who have combated Breast Cancer, or just found out they have it. It's the internal struggle they deal with that rips at them, creating a void within. The 5 stages of Breast Cancer are depicted through each stem of the Fleur De Lis. The center being one piece, or the depiction of two breasts. It's a reminder that no matter what, you're still beautiful, but most importantly, your beauty within.

 

Other Artwork:

Below are more beautiful works of art by me, that depict the struggles and beauty in life.

  • Depicts the beauty and struggles in life.
  • Full of vibrancy and emotion, the power of art.

 

Name: Aesthetics

Aesthetics stands for beauty in itself, the power of external and internal beauty. With hope and faith, beauty flurishes, and anything is possible. The power of hope alone has the power to make miracles happen. Be part of that miracle.

Name: Worlds Collide

Just as those who suffer with Breast cancer, there is a constant struggle between what is right, and what is wrong. The balance between good and evil, what's beautiful and what's perceived as ugly. Regardless of the internal and external struggles, both can come together and form something beautiful. Help make others realize how truly beautiful they are.

Name: Rememberance


Rememberance stands for those who have suffered from Breast Cancer, and will always have a place within our own hearts and memories. The elegance of colors along with the mirrored effect stands for beauty in itself. Past and present, you're beautiful, outside and within.

 

Name: Desolate


Many of those who suffer with and have lost from Breast Cancer, or have family members who have, are Desolate. The struggles they face and the lack of awareness makes a person feel singled out, and as if others just don't truly understand the struggles you're going through. Desolate stands for beauty, for hope, and with the eagle and flag, it stands for unity. Unity of those around you who are willing to promote awareness, and take away the Desolate feeling those who suffer feel. Help give someone hope, and faith, and take away a small part, if not all, the feeling of Desolation. 

 

Name: Wonderland - Limited

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you cant contribute, please help spread the word and my work.

  • Share and like my campaign on facebook!
  • Send a link or message to friends and loved ones you know who might be touched by my work.

Thank you and God Bless, and please, view my other campaigns!

story:
Please help support the Calabasas Girls Learn International Chapter raise money to host the 2nd Annual Malala Visual and Performing Arts Benefit! This is an evening of art, photography, music and dance as the school comes together to fundraise for the Kushal School for Girls in Pakistan. Malala Yousafzai attended this school before she was attacked by the Taliban for standing up for education rights. The right to receive an education is crucial, so help us make that a reality across the globe! We are aiming to raise $1000 by April 2nd!

For Tickets: 

https://www.vendini.com/ticketLine/ITL/?w=381cb...

story:
Augmented Organism is a project bringing together science, art and technology with world wisdom traditions, sounds and movements. Aug Org values connection with Land. Aug Org sees nature as an intelligent voice. Aug Org's purpose is to create globally relevant art by supporting the voice of our natural world & use technologies of today and tomorrow as tools to connect us back to the wisdom of Mother Earth. Aug Org's vision is to reinstill presence in our communities and deepen awareness within ourselves.


Production Process and Products

Highly focused experimentation and the development of digital and physical interdisciplinary artwork requires optimum environmental working conditions. Arteles Creative Centre offers quality controlled studio environments as well as external environmental art areas for developing both indoor and outdoor work. Cy and Jaz, in consultation and collaboration with Neil Harbisson, will generate the following work derived from interdisciplinary experimentation and augmentation of interactions between 'organism' and 'environment':

  • A tourable AugOrg live performance - including physical movement, sonochromatic AV-design, photography, video & text.
  • AugOrg archival video of the live performance
  • A series of experimental 'Aug Org' videos based on practice based research areas (read more about these areas of research below)
  • AugOrg film series - 4 short dance films
  • AugOrg - The Album - A journey into the sound of augmented organisms
  • Workshop module based on the processes of making AugOrg
  • Practice based academic research documentation & media material
  • Public & Private Video Log subscriptions - during and after the residency
  • One or more websites containing access to the above material

Stretch Goal Productions - (If project funding reaches or exceeds €14, 000)

  • A Virtual Reality or Augmented Reality short film/meditation experience based on AugOrg Transmedia assets - combining original music, sound design, vocal meditations, photography (and potentially video) from AugOrg as well as additional visual designs all within a fully immersive VR experience


Meet the Artists


Interdisciplinary artists Cy Gorman (AUS) and Jazmyne Koch (GER/USA) met at the 2014 World Dance Alliance Global Summit in Angers, France, where they were both showcasing choreographic works that presented unique perspectives on contemporizing the past and envisioning the future. They immediately recognized a shared passion for creatively expressing theimportance of the individual'sinterconnected relationship with Mother Nature and the art of storytelling with film.

In 2015, Cy and Jaz began a transnational new media/film research project exploring states of liminality and presence by combining mythological "goddess" archetypes within various physical & digital environments.

In the latter half of 2015, Cy met cyborg artist and activist Neil Harbisson (SPN/USA). The two formed another transnational creative collaboration and Cy began integrating Neil's sonochromatic files into both his audio and visual designs. This additional contribution from Neil, combined with the developing languages of Cy and Jaz's work, sparked the interest of one of the most renowned creative residency centres in Scandinavia and broader Europe - The Arteles Creative Residency Center. 

The Arteles Creative Residency Center have invited Cy and Jaz in collaboration and consultation with Neil Harbisson to develop their individual and collective AugOrg work and practice in Finland during the month of June, 2016. 



Creative Residency Funding & Support

WHY CROWD FUND THIS PROJECT? Funding for artists in completely different countries is not an easy task. Yes, individual funding in each country is possible but easier said than done for collaborative artist residencies as it is seen as a personal artist development, not something helping a particular community. For artists like Jazmyne for example, she doesn't fit many of the requirements to apply for funding -- Now a resident of Germany, some U.S. funding can't apply to her. In Germany, there is funding for travel, but most all require artists to travel outside of the EU, create a theater production in Germany, or attend a residency within Germany. Getting this incredible project to Finland is not an easy task.

For the combined efforts of this inspired visionary trio to progress they need to take this opportunity to finally work together in a very focused and together way. Arteles Center has recognized the potential of the trio and offered what they can to support this work. Now it's your turn!! The costs to get to Arteles, and the living and project supplies they will need for the month of June 2016 are as follows:

Arteles Residency Combined Expenses - June 2016                                     
International Round Trip Airfares                                                                                           3000
Finland Travel Costs      315
50% Remaining Residency Accom Fee    1480
Living Expenses   2660
Set/Costume/Prop/Fabrication/Installation   2355
Media/Post Production Promo/Website/Digital launch     890
Production, Crew, and additional AV hire/Tech support
   3300


Total 14,000
If the overall funding goal isn't achieved any/all funds will go to the most immediately pressing expenses such as residency cost, flights and living expenses.

Risks & Challenges

The AugOrg team have conducted an in depth risk assessment of all  "worst case/best case" scenarios for this residency including the generation of production outcomes and perks. They have already taken huge leaps of faith in dedicating pre-production development time and self generated funding from personal income.

With €10, 000 - The team is going to Finland!! Thank you!! 10k is the least funding needed to make this residency remotely possible. (This does not including recouping preproduction development costs of €1600). The circumstance is just good enough to 'break even', covering all: travel, residency tuition, living expenses, and Set/Costume/Prop/Fabrication/Installation costs! They will be working under higher pressure to produce work within lesser means (less production/tech support). Any unforeseen expenses, as well as post-production work would be on the shoulders of the artists.. 

With €12,000  - The team is going to Finland with a big smile!! The team may not be able to acquire all the optimum equipment, extra tech support & AV hire or fund their stretch goal post production & media creations BUT under these circumstances they would work with a little extra support and equipment.

With €14,000 - The team is going to Finland with a giddy joy and uncontrollable excitement!!! The team can produce under optimum working conditions with FULL cover of additionally required equipment & tech support to create this project in its entirety and fullest potential. The stretch goal of the VR (Virtual Reality) experience will also be completed!!


Why Finland & The Arteles Center?


The Arteles Creative Center provides the best environment for the production phase of Augmented Organism. Located  in the countryside of Hämeenkyrö, in the area of Haukijärvi, the artists will be in direct contact with nature with easy access to lakes and forests for their field research, yet have access to nearby towns for any supplies they will need along the way. They will also work with the Arteles logistical & production staff as well as have access to the local social, creative, technical and administrative networks for support. Arteles makes the perfect experimental station for research in reevaluating the balance & integration of the technological/physical realms, and the balance between mind/body/spirit. We will creatively study and practice new ways of bridging physical and digital environmental conditions.

Why practice based research?

Highly focused creative exploration and production pipelines often yield breakthroughs for research and development in communities of all kinds. During the AugOrg Residency, a deep dive will be taken into creative practice based research that is highly geared towards production techniques that explore relationships between the following:

1) Technology and Mythology - Technological advancement and various aspects of mythological psychology, animal, human and plant archetypes, rites of passage, ceremony, ritual and healing. 

2) Communication - Digital communication & networking concepts and their effect on the nature of non-digital relationships and environments.

3) Geomatics, Thermal and Data Visualization - Geomatics, also known as geospatial technology is the discipline of gathering, storing, processing, and delivering geographic information, or spatially referenced information. 

4) Biomagnetics - The field of Biomagnetics defines and explores examples of naturally occurring or artificially created magnetic fields and different organisms' relationships to these magnetic fields. 


Their residency process and production outcomes can involve and engage you in a number of ways. Check out the PERKS if you want to get more involved and if you want to learn more of the details, take a dive into the extended video below!

Share the love!

Thank you, thank you, THANK you for taking time to check out our campaign! If you like what you see and you feel that we have something special, please share with your social media feeds and email your connections (the ones who love to hear about super cool exciting stuff!). Spreading the word in your unique voice and way, helps more people check us out, see what we are offering, and support our goal! :)

There is a saying from The Best Marigold Hotel that goes something like this: "Mostly things don't always happen the way you'd expect it, but it's the things that happen instead...That's the good stuff!" Believe in the 'good stuff' that happens when you are least expecting it, and trust that it all works out for the best.

Thank you, thank you, THANK YOU for your support and for "jumping in the deep end" with us! Its people like you that keep the world spinning with joy and amazing growth for the future with all in mind.

To big discoveries, to changing our times, to wanting better for our world.

                 We will leave you with this statement, one that we ask of ourselves: 

                 "He ʻike ʻana ia i ka pono" - "See the right thing to do and do it"

story:
Galaxy Lifestyle goes far above and beyond just simply teaching Aerial Yoga and other classical yoga methods. Instead, our studio promotes a healthy lifestyle, community enrichment, self-expression and love. This is achieved through aerial yoga fitness; nutrition workshops; donation based classes, where all of the funds received are given back to the community and by providing an environment where instructors focus on teaching how to find one’s self-expression and embrace it!


Furthermore, unlike a typical yoga studio, Galaxy Lifestyle takes a different personal approach to each and every class. Take for example Aerial Burlesque Class whose basic principles are a combination of sexy choreography and aerial yoga tricks. This class is meant for you to tap into your unique inner sensual soul so you too will feel comfortable in your own skin and experience new energy, growth and mind body connection. Just come to have fun and not worry if you screw up, as long as you give it all you’ve got. People of all levels are welcome to this class.


However, having great unique classes is only the beginning of our ultimate goal.


Ultimately, through your support, Galaxy Lifestyle hopes to spark an Aerial Yoga health revolution. We hope that in our new more spacious home we can accommodate more clientele and therefore make an even bigger impact. Not only that, but we also hope that our new studio will provide a safe haven where everyone is encouraged to find their self-expression and embrace it!


Aerial Yoga involves performing a series of exercises inspired by yoga, Pilates, calisthenics and aerial acrobatics in a hammock-like apparatus (silk), in order to achieve a total-body workout. Or to make it simpler: think Cirque du Soleil for yoga lovers (yogis).


Apart from being a major stress-reliever due to its high fun quotient, there are some serious health benefits associated with Aerial Yoga. One of which is relieving back pain. Anyone that has back issues should be doing Aerial Yoga, as it gives you the chance to hang freely, allowing your spine to lengthen. People who have taken the class here always comment on how much better their backs feels afterward.

 

In addition to decompressing the spine, Aerial Yoga provides a workout that allows you to stretch and strengthen without over stressing your joints or compressing your vertebrae. If that is not enough, Aerial Yoga also helps to increase strength and flexibility, as well as bring you greater awareness of your body creating a real mind-body-spirit experience.

Tracy (T Mac) Gittens began her yoga journey on a trip to Spain with her mother and twin sister. She obtained her yoga certification in New York City with Yoga Works in Manhattan. Tracy instructs Hatha, Vinyasa, Prenatal, Yin Recovery techniques, and specializes in Aerial Yoga. In the practice of yoga, concentrating on breath control as a means to still the mind and bring awareness into the body, each asana (pose) is an opportunity for yogis (practicing students) to reconnect with their body, and build strength, endurance, flexibility, and positive energy. The yogic path of respecting oneself, respecting others, and aligning oneself with the world has a profound effect on all aspects of T Mac’s life and is an adventure she would love to share with yogis in this galaxy. She enjoys sharing her knowledge and energy with her fellow yogis.


Other Ways You Can Help


  • Galaxy Lifestyle will appreciate any kind of help whether that is coming in for volunteer opportunities or internships.
story_txt: Galaxy Lifestyle goes far above and beyond just simply teaching Aerial Yoga and other classical yoga methods. Instead, our studio promotes a healthy lifestyle, community enrichment, self-expression and love. This is achieved through aerial yoga fitness; nutrition workshops; donation based classes, where all of the funds received are given back to the community and by providing an environment where instructors focus on teaching how to find one’s self-expression and embrace it!Furthermore, unlike a typical yoga studio, Galaxy Lifestyle takes a different personal approach to each and every class. Take for example Aerial Burlesque Class whose basic principles are a combination of sexy choreography and aerial yoga tricks. This class is meant for you to tap into your unique inner sensual soul so you too will feel comfortable in your own skin and experience new energy, growth and mind body connection. Just come to have fun and not worry if you screw up, as long as you give it all you’ve got. People of all levels are welcome to this class.However, having great unique classes is only the beginning of our ultimate goal.Ultimately, through your support, Galaxy Lifestyle hopes to spark an Aerial Yoga health revolution. We hope that in our new more spacious home we can accommodate more clientele and therefore make an even bigger impact. Not only that, but we also hope that our new studio will provide a safe haven where everyone is encouraged to find their self-expression and embrace it!Aerial Yoga involves performing a series of exercises inspired by yoga, Pilates, calisthenics and aerial acrobatics in a hammock-like apparatus (silk), in order to achieve a total-body workout. Or to make it simpler: think Cirque du Soleil for yoga lovers (yogis). Apart from being a major stress-reliever due to its high fun quotient, there are some serious health benefits associated with Aerial Yoga. One of which is relieving back pain. Anyone that has back issues should be doing Aerial Yoga, as it gives you the chance to hang freely, allowing your spine to lengthen. People who have taken the class here always comment on how much better their backs feels afterward.  In addition to decompressing the spine, Aerial Yoga provides a workout that allows you to stretch and strengthen without over stressing your joints or compressing your vertebrae. story:
Art the Wonder Bus’ Big Adventure

He turned our heads the moment we saw him. A big turquoise and white Nevada Division of Forestry bus was parked in a pasture near Alturas California. And he was for sale.

Wow we all thought. A bus like that would change our annual Burning Man expeditions. No more expensive big trucks to rent to haul gear for our camp of nine or ten burners, which included our Burning Man art car, the Wonder Wagon stagecoach and the team of 12 wonder ponies. A big bus like this would definitely bring joy to our Burning man community. We decided to think about it.

The bus filled our Wonder Camp musings all week. If it was still parked in the pasture on our way back to Washington, we would snag the phone number and call when we got home. Being able to buy and caretake a big bus just seemed so unlikely but what the heck we all crossed our fingers and set our intentions.

Our collective energy worked and one week after the 2010 Burn, the 26’ decommissioned fire crew bus sat in our Tacoma driveway. What a find. We immediately named him Art the Wonder Bus. Art was already partially converted to a camper bus and was a Burning man veteran, having gone to a couple Burns with his previous owner Sam. Sam had picked him up at a vehicle auction when Nevada upgraded their fleet of fire crew buses. This bus had been stationed in Tonopah, Nevada and was crewed by minimum security prisoners. Art had history.

Our Tacoma area Burner friends pitched in with us to make modest improvements so Art would be ready for the 2011 Burn. A bigger kitchen counter, overhead cabinet doors, a sound system, curtains, roof top rack for bikes. Nothing too fancy. Just a Burner bus.

Art the Wonder Bus was a hit at Burning Man 2011. He became the hub for our Wonder Camp like no rental truck ever could. As it turns out Art is a hub for several communities, not just Burning Man. Over time Art has made himself useful to local post-Burning Man events, outdoor groups and the music arts community, and the political community. Events and organizations such as Burning Man, Seacompression, Ignition Northwest, Occupy Tacoma, Titanium Sporkestra, Honk Fest West, and the Tacoma Mountaineers. When Art joined our family, we had no idea how useful and beloved he would become. His potenial contributions were unknown but clearly we have gone from the owners to the caretakers. That’s why when we learned Art the Wonder Bus had been stolen from his rural home on Key Peninsula, many people cried “Noooooo.” OK, we might have yelled some other words too.

The bus apparently turned the heads of some thieves too. They did not see his magic and his gifts to the community. The tweakers just saw a hunk of metal to plunder for a few dollars at a scrap yard. So they stole Art. They jammed a screwdriver into Art’s central nervous system and twisted. Art groaned and turned over. The tweakers drove him through the unbolted gate and away in the darkness. Five days later, he was found only 3 miles from his home, as the crow flies. But he was buried so deep in dense woods that he might as well have been in India. We would have never seen him just scouting around. If the thieves had more time, they were going to flip him over and continue to butcher him as they had done to the other stolen and stripped vehicles around him.

With the help of an amazing tow truck operator we pulled Art from a potential final resting place back to our place and have begun the restoration work.

That’s where all who view this slide show come in to play. Art needs financial aid to continue his life journey serving diverse communities. What the thieves stripped will cost about $4,000 to replace. We will do all the work but need help to buy the following items that were stolen: radiator, battery and cables, windshield, electrical control panel, stereo and speakers, mirrors, sun visor, defrost fans, wiring harnesses, wheel chocks, fire extinguisher, first aid kit, gray water barrels, awning conduit, miscellaneous tools, bottle jack, tow hitch, tow chain, triangle reflectors, rebar stakes, and the rescue towing charge.

Thank you for letting us share the story of Art the Wonder Bus. If his story and his potential compels you to donate money to Art’s restoration work, we would be humbled and grateful. And many communities would benefit from your generousity. In the future, Art will be parked in a more secure location!

story:
Photo above: Jess and Garrett of We Heart New York

LUMEN 2011: A SUCCESS!

Lumen 2011 was a huge success! Thank you to the over 2,000 guests and LUMEN lovers who came out for a beautiful Summer evening on Staten Island's waterfront - hijacked by contemporary artists and curators. COAHSI is very proud!

BUT... We still need your help! Help us reach our fundraising goal for LUMEN 2011!

Support contemporary art in NYC AND on Staten Island!


Check out some awesome photos by LUMEN 2011 lovers!!!


Artist: Jason Peters
Photo by: Jess and Garrett of We Heart New York

Artist: Igor Baloste
Photo by: Jess and Garrett of We Heart New York

Grace Exhibition Space
Photo by: Jess and Garrett of We Heart New York

Artist: Quinn Dukes McDivitt
Photo by: Jess and Garrett of We Heart New York
Artist: Lisa Dahl
Photo by: Jess and Garrett of We Heart New York

Artists: Erik Sanner and Kazue Taguchi
Photo by: Jess and Garrett of We Heart New York

The BackStory

Photo by Mike Shane Photography

LUMEN is an outdoor video and performance art festival featuring cutting edge work by established and emerging artists with raw, decrepit warehouses as the backdrop. It is in its second year, bringing over 800 people to Staten Island's waterfront for this single largest contemporary art one-day event in Staten island's history.



In addition to the video projections, there are a full-range of performance art events happening throughout the day, courtesy of Grace Exhibition Space in Brooklyn.  These performance art events keep the audience involved as we wait for the sun to set and the projectors start to roll.


Photo by Paul Moakely


From narrative to avant-garde to sound-based, from local to international, LUMEN has got it all.


What You Can Expect

LUMEN 2011 will be held at the Lighthouse Museum Coastguard site just steps east of the SI Ferry terminal. Head curator Ginger Shulick will be accompanied by four guest curators and close to 100 artists from Staten Island and beyond. 


  • Denise Carvalho
  • Jill McDermid and Erik Hokanson of Grace Exhibition Space
  • Natalia Mount
  • Peter Duhon of Art Comments
  • Paul Moakley

Check out www.lumenfest.org for the list of artists participating in 2011 and up to date information.


What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise approximately $2000 to cover our costs. These funds will help cover permit fees, equipment rentals and help pay our artists and curators. In turn you will receive cool perks and original artist work by Lisa Dahl, Steven Lapcevic and Paul Moakely.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please pass this viral campaign along to your friends. Additionally, if your pockets are all linty but you'd still like to help out, we can use your help setting up, breaking down and everywhere in-between. Please contact Monica Valenzuela at mvalenzuela@statenislandarts.org or 718-447-3329 x 1004 to see how you can help.

story:
Short Summary

In 2013 Tommy Vext partnered with Aaron Robin to form a unique non-profit organization aptly named SFG12. SFG12's mission is to offer uniquely curtailed financial and spiritual assistance programs to individuals seeking relief from addiction and be a source of information and support for their families and loved ones.

What We Do

Our services help people in their time of need. When you or someone you love or are concerned about needs help with drug and or alcohol addiction, we are a lifeline for you to reach out to. SFG12 aims to offer a wide range of sober support to those in need:

1) Customized treatment needs
2) Uniquely designed financial programs
3) Spiritual assistance programs
4) Sponsorship
5) Peer support groups
6) Sober living
7) Detox admissions
8) Community Outreach
9) Presence at Festivals and Events
10) Youth Outreach Program - “Never Had a Legal Drink"
11) An Online Meeting Platform

Hi, my name is Aaron Robin.  I am the co-founder and CEO of SFG12. 

My story is simple and a bit cliché amongst most who’ve won the battle with drug and alcohol addiction: I had drank and used with reckless disregard for long enough, had hit rock bottom, and in 2006 made a conscious decision to get sober and turn my life around.  Looking back now, that decision was the single most important moment in my life and quite possibly the best thing I have ever done.

Fast forward to 2013, when I reunited with long-time friend Tommy Vext and first heard about SFG.  His commitment to helping others inspired me to do the same and so SFG12 was born.  Cleaning up my life has been the hardest thing I’ve ever faced.  While I’ve had the good fortune of supportive friends and family along the way, there are those less fortunate than I who are in desperate need of support to help them overcome their addiction. 

During these last eight years of sobriety, I have seen a lot of people struggle to get clean. I’ve come to realize just how challenging dealing with an addiction can be.  It is a ruthless disease that affects both those afflicted and those whose lives are closely tied to the sufferer. 

I made a decision in September to change my life in an effort to change many more. Thank you everybody for the support. I’m so excited to be part of SFG12!

"When we first founded SFG12 it was based on Recovery, Community & Service, But the more its mission has grown the more I've realized it's service is filling a necessity. My Dream is to one day see SFG12 as an organization that saves lives for those who cant afford it, and to ever remain an open door. An open door for those like me, who couldn't hear the message of sobriety until it came from not just another addict / alcoholic, but from another artist." Tommy Vext - Board Member 

Since our Founding on September 11th, 2013 SFG12 has impacted the community and has proven to be a lifeline to those struggling. We have only had the possibility of doing so by the enormous amount of support that we have received from all of you. Together you can help us to win the fight. 

"It was a privilege to support SFG12 through their recent Art Show. The work they are doing to help those in need is both courageous and vital. Aaron Robin continues to work tirelessly to ensure that those struggling and seeking recovery always have a place to turn." Shervin Pishevar - CEO of Sherpa Ventures

"SFG12 supports those who so desperately need help but do not have them means to help themselves. When I first saw this organization in action I knew I had to do all  I could to show my support. Aaron Robin works tirelessly to ensure that those in need always have a place to turn. It has been an honor to support this organization and I have no doubt they will continue to change the lives of those struggling with alcoholism and addiction." Isabelle Wright - COS to Shervin Pishevar

Changing the Conversation

Through our fundraising events, ambassadorship program, community outreach and social media presence, SFG12 aims to change the conversation around alcoholism and addiction, reducing the stigma and showing those in need that life goes on once recovery begins.

One of the biggest hurdles many face when making the decision to enter into recovery (and throughout the recovery process) is the ability to visualize a life without drugs or alcohol that will be worth living.

With the help of young professionals and those in the creative industries, alongside various community outreach programs, we aim to offer hope of a better life to those who aren’t yet able to comprehend what that means and often holds people back from making one of the hardest and most life altering decisions they will ever be faced with. 

“I’ve always hoped I’d be able to give back to those similarly afflicted by addiction as I once was.  SFG12 offers me that opportunity.  Once I heard Aaron’s conviction to ensure SFG12 become a success, I knew I was backing the right man, the right vision.  I am honored to play a small role in helping SFG12 find its footing, in turn I get to see talented men and women’s lives turned around by SFG12’s brave work.” Zac Levine  - Chairman of Board at SFG12 - LLCP

"SFG12 is real. They have helped myself and our company in many delicate situations. I urge you to pledge and show your support to inspire others and genuinely change lives. Alcoholism effects everyone around an alcoholic. SFG12’s unique way of resolving and guiding all aspects of a person recovery is second to none." Seb Webber - Board Member - Red Light Lead Artist Manager

Media

The SFG12 Facebook page is fast becoming a source of assistance for those with no where else to turn. Below is an example of one of the many messages we received in January 2014.

“Hello my name is ——— and I'm currently battling painkiller addiction,I was taking about 25-30 norco a day or 8-10 30mg percocet a day. I am a new father and recently engaged. I quit drinking about 6 months ago and then started back up with the pain killers. I started heavy drinking and pain killers abuse all while being in various bands. I’ve Been abusing painkillers on and off since high school. I'm 28 years old. Last weekend I detoxed at home and went cold turkey for about 4
days. Today is my 1st day back to work and I gave in and took some norcos I'm having a really hard time with this and am trying to get off these, I can't afford a treatment center because I will loose my job. At this point I’m just trying to get help and guidance, I live in —————, ——. My # is ——————. Please help! Thank you,” January 2014

We at SFG12 receive numerous messages daily from those looking for support and guidance. This is what our organization does.

We help people that ask for help. No strings attached and for Free!

The Hand Of SFG12 Will Always Be There To Hold When Someone Needs It 

"Having witnessed first-hand the pain caused by addiction in young adults, I'm honored to be able to support Aaron and his team at SFG12. They are doing important work to support those who would not know where to turn otherwise."
Mike Walsh - Structure.vc



Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Follow us at https://www.facebook.com/SFG12

"Having witnessed first-hand the pain caused by addiction in young adults, I'm honored to be able to support Aaron and his team at SFG12. They are doing important work to support those who would not know where to turn otherwise."Mike Walsh - Structure.vc
Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help: 
Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!
Follow us at https://www.facebook.com/SFG12

story:
Our Story


The Pueblo of Acoma Senior Center is a not-for-profit that provides vital services to community members 50-years-old or older. These services include health education sessions, health screenings, arts and crafts, inter-generational activities, transportation assistance and many others to over 150 Acoma elders. We are the only program in the entire Pueblo that transports community members to crucial doctor's appointments and on basic errands to the grocery store or bank. 

Situated in Central New Mexico halfway between Albuquerque and Gallup, Acoma is the oldest continually inhabited Native American pueblo in the United States dating back to 1100 AD. There are over 4,000 enrolled tribal members. More than 2,800 members live on tribal lands that cover 702 square miles. The region where Acoma is located once experienced an economic boom with the onset of uranium mining in the 1950â€™s but toward the end of the 1980â€™s the industry busted leaving the area economically depressed and spiritually wounded--the mine was located on the Acomaâ€™s sacred mountain, Mount Taylor.  Today, unemployment in the Acoma Community is at 51%, with 27% of the population living below poverty levels. 

 

 

The Impact

 

A West African storyteller once told me â€œWhen an elder dies, itâ€™s as if a library has been burnedâ€, and that is particularly true for the Pueblo for Acoma. Keres, the Acoma language, is in danger of being lost forever because grandmothers and grandfathers who are fluent in Keres are not living long enough to teach their â€œBabasâ€, or grandchildren, their traditional language and traditions. The Acoma population is aging rapidly. The life expectancy for Native Americans is lower than that of all other races in the US: 65 years old, and 73 for non-Native Americans.  Keres is not a written language, and storytelling is an oral tradition, so what happens when that language barrier cannot be crossed? Entire histories--stories of love, hardship, and creativity--fade into the past, and a generation grows up completely ignorant of their cultural identity. By recording stories and songs told in Keres, personal histories and messages for future generations, we can make sure this doesnâ€™t happen in Acoma. 

 

 

What We Need 

With $1,000 our program can buy recording equipment and pay for a part time media coordinator to look after the studio and teach computer literacy classes and workshops on audio editing software to the entire community for one year. Currently, we have a spare room that we will be a perfect studio space. The Acoma Language Retention Program has generously donated a Mac desktop computer, and we'll use Audacity, a free audio editing software,  to edit our work (thank god we don't have to buy Adobe Audition...for now), but you can help us purchase equipment that is crucial to any quality recording studio space:


â€¨External Hard Drive - $130.00â€¨

Wav Recorder - $200.00â€¨

Condenser Mic - $100.00

â€¨Speakers - $45.00

â€¨Headphones - $25.00

Part Time Media Coordinator for one year- $500

Total: $1000.000


We expect the Storytelling Studio to be fully functional by this Summer, 2012. 


Check out our projected timeline:


â€¨Januaryâ€¨- Recruit media coordinator and volunteersâ€¨-Fundraise for studio equipment â€¨-Go door to door advertising studioâ€¨-Make sample recordings of elders to share with Acoma's tribal government


February â€¨- Schedule Future Voices of New Mexico documentary presentationâ€¨- Plan for Santa Ana Pueblo and Acoma Language Retention Programâ€™s audio storybook Presentation to elders and communityâ€¨-Install Egg Cartons as soundproofing and clear out spare room for studio spaceâ€¨ 


Marchâ€¨-Go to Acoma Laguna High School and Sky City School to advertise the projectâ€¨-Create audio storybooks in Keres (the Acoma language) for the Acoma Language Retention Center


April - May

-Create â€œinterview kitsâ€ with helpful questions and guidelines for interviewers 

-Advertise studio opening-Continue to teach elders how to use equipment


June

Have a fully functional, accessible studio space where community members can come and record their personal histories, identities, and messages to one-another and for future generations. All recordings will be archived in the Puebloâ€™s library and will not be made available to the public.

 

Folks, if we reach our entire goal and this studio is built by June 2012 it will be used immediately by the Pueblo's Learning Center, who just received an exciting, two-year Institute of Museum and Library Services (IMLS) grant. This grant allows Acoma youth to interview their elders and create two books, one about Acoma's traditional Native history, industry, and government, and another about contemporary Acoma life and struggles. This Storytelling Recording Studio will make it easier for Acoma youth to interview their grandparents, because the studio is in the Acoma Senior Center!  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Ask your friends to get the word out and make some noise about our Storytelling Studio!

story:
The video is from my first exhibit you get an example of what my work is.

Short Summary

Hello Indie gogo Fam

My name is Suritah Wignall and I am a visual artist from Toronto Ontario. I have been practicing art for more that 15 years and have been trying to do it professionally for the last 5 years. My works show the beauty of my culture as an Afro-Caribbean Canadian Woman and the the beauty of woman. i love painting, shapes, skin tones, hair, textures and features as i am truly fascinated by woman. And My medium of choice is Acrylic, Oil, Cloths, mixed media and Japanese Paper

My Campaign

My campaign is that I have been invoted to have my first solo exhibition at a venue called La Comidilla in Seville, Spain. well, i am going to be truly honest,  i have never wanted to so badly but to live my life and do what it is i love to do. i believe that everyone should live out their passion. That is a birth right. but some of are more privileged than most, especially folks like us who have access to internet and contribute in this amazing way. Art and Creating is my Love, it has got me through some of the toughest times in my life, times where i did not even think i was going to make through certain situations. but to live as an artist is a gift.

The Magnitude

All i keep thinking about and this brings me to tears is that my grandpa is an 80 year old man who has had an open heart surgery and still has to work, because he cant pay his bills, my grandpa currently lives in miami and how my mom had to give up her dreams of being a couture designer to raise 3 girls as a single parent. I believe in working hard and anything that it is you love to do and because of them, i bust my ass off, because if they could sacrifice so much for me, what i can do is work hard to accomlish things that they werent able to. Especially as they grew up in Jamaica and i had the good fortune of growing up here in Toronto. I absolutely adore my grandpa, even when i would get write ups in community paper and mail it to him, he would tell the whole neighbourhood i was famous. LOL. and would always say, "as long as your happy baby"

 

 What We Need & What You Get

the funding i currently need is $1500 and its going to the airfare to Spain, because i am asking in such a short period of time, i feel that i would ask for the most important cost, which is my flight to Spain. Flights are not cheap, forunately i know people in Spain, that i can stay with, but at moment i cant aford the flight there. I have also applied to grants to help fund this project. but as we know grants are not always certain. this is my first time going the community route, which is eciting for me

If you help to fund this project, one of the perks is a print of your choice in the print section of my website. www.sweetlikemango.com and if i dont recive full funding, the funds raised will still go to airflight costs

 

The Impact:

Being invited to exhibit my work in neighbourhood, where the focus is Flamenco is such an honour, it would be the first time the owner would exhibit works from an artist of Afro Caribbean descent, this is a mile stone for the neighbourhood and for myself to share my expereinces through my art as a woman of color.

I have had the opportunity to collaborate with Eryakh Badu, won an entepreneiural award from The University of Toronto in 2011, received numerous grants for my community work especially working with women who are survivors of vilence facilitating free art workshops and now having the opportunity to exhibit in Spain as my first international exhibition is such a huge stepping stone in my career as i feel it will open up many doors for me in sharing my creativity with the world

Other Ways You Can Help

the other ways you can hel is maybe you would like to donate airmiles that you are not using as i feel that would be considerably helpful as well, so if you or anyone you know has extra airmiles they would like to donate for my first solo exhibit that would be such an honor as well maybe you would like some art. you can order my art at www.sweetlikemango.com. please use the indie gogo share tools. I thank you so much for reading and your support on my creative journey. I will be creating a new video of my up to date art as the video is from my first solo exhibit

story:
We have made our indiegogo goal! From the bottom of our big rusty heart, thank you to everyone who donated. If you would still like to contribute, more donations = more fire. Can't wait to light up the playa

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

New Reward Just Added! The makers of "SPARK: A Burning Man Story" are contributing 10 copies of their film's upcoming DVD release to support our Indiegogo campaign! Check out the trailer here.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Heartfullness is a 12 by 15 foot steel sculpture of a heart that has been repeatedly broken and pieced back together. While it may be damaged and pieces may be missing, this weathered heart is stronger and infinitely more interesting. The sculpture made it's debut at Burning Man 2012, and we would like to bring it again in 2013, but with a few (fiery) upgrades.

Heartfullness was built to allow exploration of the interior space. Climb inside and curl up in the love seats made out of woven rope. The interior structure is made of triangulated steel and covered by re-claimed sheet metal pieced together to represent a beautiful reconstructed heart. Red LEDs illuminate the sculpture at night.

With your help, this experience will be brought to the next level, with not one but two types of fire. Inside the heart will be plasma tubes where balls of fire swirl around the people sitting inside. At the top of the heart will be six poofers that blast fire high into the sky when you pull at the "heart strings". This will be a unique experience where fire elements are interactive and enjoyed intimately when viewed from inside the heart, as well as an exciting visual when viewied from outside.

Have you had your heart broken by romance, the loss of a loved one, illness or other forms of heartbreak? Help us bring Heartfullness back to Burning Man 2013 to provide a haven of comfort and love for all hearts to mend, and an exciting display of fire and passion. Your donation of any size will help. You can also help by spreading the word, please share this project with your friends and family.

We need help paying for materials for the upgrades, additional lighting and transportation to Burning Man. We have some great ways to thank you for your donation. We have planned a one of a kind bus tour of San Francisco and other fun ways to interact with our crew. We also have some sweet swag. If you can't decide on just one, order the multipack or donate multiple times!

It has been my dream to create this sculpture since I first envisioned it at Burning Man 2007. It is the reason that I sought to learn how to weld and construct big art. It has been quite a journey to reach this point and I hope that you can join me and the crew as we transform Heartfullness into it's next incarnation.

 

Thanks for your support! 

Follow us on Facebook: facebook.com/heartfullnessproject

story:
Here's My Story

I’m Jim McIntosh, a jewelry designer for the past ten years. During that time I have explored jewelry design from every angle imaginable. Since I never learned the rules of design, I've had the freedom to color outside of the lines. That given my work a fresh look. I hate seeing people wear jewelry that has been stamped out by the hundred's in a factory. Jewelry should reflect your personal style. So my design philosophy has always been - "Distinctive Jewelry without Duplication".

I’ve been lucky enough to help others create their own jewelry styles. For many years I've taught jewelry creation at bead stores throughout the United States. Seeing others create their own style of jewelry has been a wonderful experience.

 

Thank You For Your Help

When the economy shifted and people have less money to buy artisan jewelry, I had to cut back considerably on creating new work. So, to keep my creative passion alive and thriving, I started teaching jewelry creation and design to others.

Now I am ready to expand my vision. I want to purchase a few supplies (gemstones are expensive), and marketing materials so I can place my work in boutiques and galleries around the U.S. I also want to create a new website to show and sell my new creations. My dreams are huge!

I have beautiful, hand-made jewelry I would like to offer in exchange for your donations. Please choose your perk from the list on the right.

Everyone Can Help in Some Way

If you can’t help financially, you can help me by copying the above “Share this Campaign” link above and send it to your friends, family and social networks. Thank you all for your support!

story:
If you still want to support us...

 

Make a contribution at www.africanvoices.com

 

We will honor the perk agreements on this page for the level of your support. Thanks!

Short Summary

African Voices, one of the few national literary magazines to dedicated to publishing African-American literature and art, will have a legacy exhibition "From Cover to Cover: 20 Years of African Voices," at the historic Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem from Dec. 8, 2012 to January 19, 2013. 

"From Cover to Cover: 20 Years of African Voices" celebrates the wealth and diverse artistic styles of contemporary African-American artists that have been published on the magazine's front and back covers for the past two decades. The exhibition will showcase the work of 20 to 25 artists and is being curated by Danny Simmons, the founder of Rush Philanthropic Arts Foundation.

African Voices Commnications, Inc. is a premier non-profit arts organization that presents artistic programming ranging from art exhibitions, literary readings, creative writing workshops to Reel Sisters, a film festival devoted presenting opportunities for women of color in the film industry.

The project will support the art exhibition and help pay for one of four 20th anniversary issues.

About the exhibition

Danny Simmons, the founder of Rush Philanthropic Arts Foundation, is the curator for the exhibition. Artwork from the magazine’s front and back covers will anchor the exhibition. Photo essays and other archival pieces will give viewers a historical perspective on African Voices’ 20-year celebration of Black art and literature. Photographer Marilyn Nance’s photographs documenting the African burial ground and Chester Higgins, Jr.’s stunning photograph of the late dance choreographer Katherine Dunham give viewers a chance to glimpse inside the magazine’s covers.  Michele Stewart’s haunting black and white sketch showing four pairs of girl legs sitting in a church pew holding hymn books captures the horror of poet Letta Simone-Nefertari Neely’s “Which patent leather shoe belong to which found leg.” The poem is dedicated to the four girls murdered in the 1963 church bombing in Birmingham, Alabama. The illustration masterfully shows the young girls living — one with a band aide on her knee — but their heads are not in the drawing, a visual sign that something unspeakable is amiss.

The exhibition will feature a rich selection of the journal’s cover artists including such distinguished artists as Faith Ringgold, Otto Neals, Justin Bua, Francks Deceus, JamesTop, Elizabeth Catlett and Verna Hart.

The front and back cover artists have established a unique visual vocabulary for the magazine's iconic literary style.

What We Need & What You Get

Your contribution will help us pay our exhibition and publication costs. The magazine is seeking $3,500 towards a $25,000 fundraising goal. The rest of the funding will come from grants, fundraising events and loyal donors.

African Voices receives funding from the New York State Council on the Arts, NYC Department of Cultural Affairs and private funders.

The economic climate has reduced the support we get so every dollar you give counts!

No contribution is too SMALL — you may donate $1, $5 or $10.

Please share our campaign on your Facebook wall and encourage friends and family to support us!

Please continue to contribute to the success of this campaign past the $3,500 goal. Why? You will bring us closer to bringing you literature and art that feeds the soul!

We have some really cool perks such as free admission to our events and a special collectors' item issue of a magazine guest edited by award winning poet Sonia Sanchez!

The Impact

African Voices selects work by talented artists at the beginning of their careers and provides a space for new artists to express themselves. Among those writers African Voices has been privileged to publish are: Pulitzer-prize winning novelist Junot Díaz  (Spring 1996); Jeffery Renard Allen (Fall/Winter 2002), the author of Rails Under; writer/playwright T. Tara Turk (Spring/Summer 2008); Elizabeth Alexander (Fall/Winter 2002), the poet selected for President Barack Obama’s 2008 inauguration celebration, appeared in the Fall/Winter 2002 issue. 

The list of fabulously gifted writers appearing on our pages, spanning two decades, is too long to list here, but a few more are: David Mills, Anne Sterling Sutton, Miriam S. Perez, Mercy Lee Tullis, Tyehimba Jess, Tara Betts, Sterling D. Plumpp, Louis Reyes Rivera, Danny Simmons, C.D. Grant, Emily Raboteau, Denizé Lauture, Willie Perdomo, asha bandele, Ted Wilson, Ibi Zoboi, and Gary Johnston.

Your contribution will give us a chance to continue to provide a space for visual artists and writers to create at a time when America is slowly losing its cultural institutions!

 

What we do besides publishing African Voices?

African Voices Communications, Inc., the non-profit arts organization that publishes the magazine, has a long history of supporting artists through several programs that touch people as young as eight years old to seventy-five years young.

We believe the arts should impact people’s lives and community activism has been a vital part of our mission since the organization’s inception.

A brief outline of our arts programming:

African Voices Cultural Circle Conference: The Circle Conference, an annual forum that connects writers and visual artists with the resources they need to pursue careers in publishing and the arts. Photo above features Ronnique Hawkins, a writer who attended a past Cultural Circle Conference.

Get Your Read On!: Young people are introduced to storytelling and creative writing workshops that nurture their interest in reading and writing.

African Voices Workshops & Performance Series: The series offers emerging writers a chance to develop their craft in weekly workshop sessions and the reading series provides a chance for independent authors to sell and share their work. 

Reel Sisters Film of the Diaspora Festival & Lecture Series: Annual film festival that presents work directed, written or produced by women filmmakers.

Ellie Charles Artists Award & Scholarship: Each year, African Voices presents the Ellie Charles Artists Awards to honor artists, community activists and other educators for their contributions to society.

 

Why should I support African Voices?

It is one of the few independent publications dedicated to ensuring that America’s literary tradition remains rich and vibrant.

 African Voices could not publish the magazine without you! African Voices has always been fueled by your stories, financial contributions and energy. 

Every dollar of your contribution will help us meet our goals in publishing a quality magazine. You will see the fruits of your contribution if you donate $40 or more — you will receive all four issues of the 20th Anniversary collection. 

We are also offering several cool incentives for you to enjoy as a thank you for your support.

DONORS LIVING OUTSIDE USA: Supporters living outside of the United States will be asked to pay for additional shipping costs for perks. 

 

For further information:

www.africanvoices.com 

 

www.reelsisters.org

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Volunteer! Please call us about volunteer opportunities:

212-865-2982.

 

Subscribe to the magazine for $20 (4 issues)!

 

Be a cheerleader and get at least five friends to contribute to our fundraising campaign!

 

Thanks for your passion and support!
story_txt:
If you still want to support us...
 
Make a contribution at www.africanvoices.com
 
We will honor the perk agreements on this page for the level of your support. Thanks!
Short Summary
African Voices, one of the few national literary magazines to dedicated to publishing African-American literature and art, will have a legacy exhibition "From Cover to Cover: 20 Years of African Voices," at the historic Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem from Dec. 8, 2012 to January 19, 2013. 
"From Cover to Cover: 20 Years of African Voices" celebrates the wealth and diverse artistic styles of contemporary African-American artists that have been published on the magazine's front and back covers for the past two decades. The exhibition will showcase the work of 20 to 25 artists and is being curated by Danny Simmons, the founder of Rush Philanthropic Arts Foundation.
African Voices Commnications, Inc. is a premier non-profit arts organization that presents artistic programming ranging from art exhibitions, literary readings, creative writing workshops to Reel Sisters, a film festival devoted presenting opportunities for women of color in the film industry.
The project will support the art exhibition and help pay for one of four 20th anniversary issues.
About the exhibition
Danny Simmons, the founder of Rush Philanthropic Arts Foundation, is the curator for the exhibition. Artwork from the magazine’s front and back covers will anchor the exhibition. Photo essays and other archival pieces will give viewers a historical perspective on African Voices’ 20-year celebration of Black art and literature. Photographer Marilyn Nance’s photographs documenting the African burial ground and Chester Higgins, Jr.’s stunning photograph of the late dance choreographer Katherine Dunham give viewers a chance to glimpse inside the magazine’s covers.  Michele Stewart’s haunting black and white sketch showing four pairs of girl legs sitting in a church pew holding hymn books captures the horror of poet Letta Simone-Nefertari Neely’s “Which patent leather shoe belong to which found leg.” The poem is dedicated to the four girls murdered in the 1963 church bombing in Birmingham, Alabama. The illustration masterfully shows the young girls living — one with a band aide on her knee — but their heads are not in the drawing, a visual sign that something unspeakable is amiss.
The exhibition will feature a rich selection of the journal’s cover artists including such distinguished artists as Faith Ringgold, Otto Neals, Justin Bua, Francks Deceus, JamesTop, Elizabeth Catlett and Verna Hart.
The front and back cover artists have established a unique visual vocabulary for the magazine's iconic literary style.
What We Need & What You Get
Your contribution will help us pay our exhibition and publication costs. The magazine is seeking $3,500 towards a $25,000 fundraising goal. The rest of the funding will come from grants, fundraising events and loyal donors.
African Voices receives funding from the New York State Council on the Arts, NYC Department of Cultural Affairs and private funders.
The economic climate has reduced the support we get so every dollar you give counts!
No contribution is too SMALL — you may donate $1, $5 or $10.
Please share our campaign on your Facebook wall and encourage friends and family to support us!
Please continue to contribute to the success of this campaign past the $3,500 goal. Why? You will bring us closer to bringing you literature and art that feeds the soul!
We have some really cool perks such as free admission to our events and a special collectors' item issue of a magazine guest edited by award winning poet Sonia Sanchez!
The Impact
African Voices selects work by talented artists at the beginning of their careers and provides a space for new artists to express themselves. Among those writers African Voices has been privileged to publish are: Pulitzer-prize winning novelist Junot Díaz  (Spring 1996); Jeffery Renard Allen (Fall/Winter 2002), the author of Rails Under; writer/playwright T. Tara Turk (Spring/Summer 2008); Elizabeth Alexander (Fall/Winter 2002), the poet selected for President Barack Obama’s 2008 inauguration celebration, appeared in the Fall/Winter 2002 issue. 
The list of fabulously gifted writers appearing on our pages, spanning two decades, is too long to list here, but a few more are: David Mills, Anne Sterling Sutton, Miriam S. Perez, Mercy Lee Tullis, Tyehimba Jess, Tara Betts, Sterling D. Plumpp, Louis Reyes Rivera, Danny Simmons, C.D. Grant, Emily Raboteau, Denizé Lauture, Willie Perdomo, asha bandele, Ted Wilson, Ibi Zoboi, and Gary Johnston.
Your contribution will give us a chance to continue to provide a space for visual artists and writers to create at a time when America is slowly losing its cultural institutions!
 
What we do besides publishing African Voices?
African Voices Communications, Inc., the non-profit arts organization that publishes the magazine, has a long history of supporting artists through several programs that touch people as young as eight years old to seventy-five years young.
We believe the arts should impact people’s lives and community activism has been a vital part of our mission since the organization’s inception.
A brief outline of our arts programming:
African Voices Cultural Circle Conference: The Circle Conference, an annual forum that connects writers and visual artists with the resources they need to pursue careers in publishing and the arts. Photo above features Ronnique Hawkins, a writer who attended a past Cultural Circle Conference.
Get Your Read On!: Young people are introduced to storytelling and creative writing workshops that nurture their interest in reading and writing.
African Voices Workshops & Performance Series: The series offers emerging writers a chance to develop their craft in weekly workshop sessions and the reading series provides a chance for independent authors to sell and share their work. 
Reel Sisters Film of the Diaspora Festival & Lecture Series: Annual film festival that presents work directed, written or produced by women filmmakers.
Ellie Charles Artists Award & Scholarship: Each year, African Voices presents the Ellie Charles Artists Awards to honor artists, community activists and other educators for their contributions to society.
 
Why should I support African Voices?
It is one of the few independent publications dedicated to ensuring that America’s literary tradition remains rich and vibrant.
 African Voices could not publish the magazine without you! African Voices has always been fueled by your stories, financial contributions and energy. 
Every dollar of your contribution will help us meet our goals in publishing a quality magazine. You will see the fruits of your contribution if you donate $40 or more — you will receive all four issues of the 20th Anniversary collection. 
We are also offering several cool incentives for you to enjoy as a thank you for your support.
DONORS LIVING OUTSIDE USA: Supporters living outside of the United States will be asked to pay for additional shipping costs for perks. 
 
For further information:
www.africanvoices.com 
 
www.reelsisters.org
 
Other Ways You Can Help
Volunteer! Please call us about volunteer opportunities:
212-865-2982.
 
Subscribe to the magazine for $20 (4 issues)!
 
Be a cheerleader and get at least five friends to contribute to our fundraising campaign!
 
Thanks for your passion and support!

story:
Tax-deductible donations can be made through September 15th via the Black Rock Arts Foundation at: http://bit.ly/1sJlfmT

Eidolon Panspermia Ostentatia Duodenum is a voronoi-inspired open-cell mycelial ovoid structure representing a possible matrix manifold of the panspermia transportation vesicle designed to inspire a profound sense of apophenia. In other words, ePOD is a 21 foot tall and 22 foot wide interactive steel sculpture featuring a rotating, climbable structure with a central lighting system. We received partial funding through an  Honorarium Burning Man grant but are still far short of the funds needed to complete a project as involved as this. So, to overcome large obstacles ahead and maintain our general mental health, we are seeking help from generous souls to bring this project to life fully. 

ePOD is a lattice work of lacy jungle gym designed specifically for its participants' pleasure. It's 5 tons of twisted spinning steel straight from your childhood dreams. After the suns sets, light will emanate from its central orb sending shadows stretching across the playa. With your help, this playground mothership will allow you and your friends to scramble and climb trans-dimensionally around the massive oblate spheroid. 

Funding

We need $15,000 to fully fund ePOD. The engineering challenges of creating a kinetic sculpture of this scale are considerable and add another level not normally encountered in the building process. Your pledge, however large, will contribute to making this creation truly come alive for people to enjoy. For those interested in a tax-deductible option, Black Rock Arts Foundation can accept donations here.

For your pledges, we're offering everything from ridiculously stupid mad props to uncomfortably long  telepresent hugs of appreciation. More seriously, we'll have signed custom metallic prints of ePOD at Burning Man from our photographer, Anne Stavely. For larger pledges, we're offering ePOD medallions, framed original concept art, and two different incredible models.

We'll keep all our supporters updated as we work towards ePOD's final installation in the Black Rock Desert.

    Challenges

    Our worst-case scenario simply means the final piece will not match our initial dream of having it move and hold a hundred people. This would be sad

    Sharing

    Please share our ePOD campaign with your friends. Community support is critical for the full realization of this participant-activated work.

story:
Demian Petryshyn: Contemporary Visual Artist, Aquarium Enthusiast

If you are into helping out please get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.

Hi, I am Demian Petryshyn, originally from Edmonton Alberta, the prairies of Western Canada. I have worked as a visual artist in Vancouver, Canada for the last ten years or so, with short stints in London Ontario to do my MFA, and Albi France to study Foucault first hand. I've been working with grunt gallery, a Vancouver based artist-run centre, for the past three years. With the help of various partners and friends like grunt, I'm getting into devloping my studio practice, and using social media to help fund the work. 

The plan is to craft a self-sustaining aquatic ecosystem in a 10-gallon aquarium tank, a kind of plant mass in water with bugs and animals and stuff, maybe even a mushroom or two; but always a work of art, a sculpture. I look at the work of Hayao Miyazaki and Amano Takashi, for example, and I see compelling ways of thinking about the world. This aquarium is styled in their tribute. Your contributions will support the refinement of my skill in this medium, helping me to learn and develop technique over the duration of the campaign. The dream is something between a garden and a forest, with biological solutions for the problems posed in establishing a healthy aquaculture.

 

What We Need to Move the Project Forward & What You Get

It’s a 10 Gallon Tank with a selection of freshwater flora and fauna. There is a shrimp, and two small snails named Jacob, Ehrich, and Mr. Wolf respectively. There are three fish too, but they are likely too busy to be bothered (although they enjoy the food pellets). Contributions can be made in the following categories to help with the tank's evolution: 

  • Temperature
  • Oxygen Levels
  • General Hardness ppm (mg/L) Fresh: GH
  • Carbonate Hardness ppm (mg/L) Fresh: KH
  • pH Fresh: pH
  • Nitrite ppm (mg/L) Fresh: NO2-
  • Nitrate ppm (mg/L) Fresh: NO3-
  • CO2 Levels
  • R&D - Web Streaming, Minecraft. . .  

Come back to this site to check out the progress as new perks and content become available during the course of the project. The smallest contributions have a big impact in keeping the project active. 

Special perks also include a selection of drawings, mini projects, and ultimately ownership of the finished still-water aquarium.

While I would love to make this the coolest thing ever, it's not a life and death thing. If the campaign goal is not reached I just won't be able to put as much of my time into the tank as I would want. That's it; it will still meet my goals, be dear to my heart, and be interesting as a work of art. Patience is at the heart of this game. 

 

The Impact

This is a form of expression that is very much routed in the meeting of efficiency and happenstance; a chance to learn and enjoy. Semiotics in 3D.

 

To contact me directly please email: Demian Petryshyn dpetryshyn@gmail.com
