story:
POWER PLAN!

Hello gamers, collectors, Deviant Art followers, Facebook lurkers, Tumblr Noters, Instagramers, and new fans alike! Welcome to my first Power Prints Drive!

You know the deal, every year I draw tons of commish and use them to fund my way to cons and such. But this next year is special, cause I actually want to go to more cons than my usual California/Arizona mix, so we gotta move inventory. Luckily, with Christmas right around the corner all my fans have been asking me for X-Mas gifts to post up, so here ya go, a bunch of high quality 11x17 full color print sets featuring hand drawn and colored (in Copics and watercolor for most of them) gaming prints to appease the collecting masses. 

NOW YOUR COLLECTING WITH POWER!

I have 8 different sets, 5 prints to a set priced at $45 each. As a bonus you'll also get a 90pg DRM Free digital sketchbook! It collects  everything from my last print drive and has over 100 pics to boot. Sounds great right? Here are the art packs.


SOLID PACK HIRES LINK

MEGA 01 PACK HIRES LINK

MEGA 02 PACK HIRES LINK

NINJA PACK HIRES LINK

NOIR PACK HIRES LINK

DARK PACK HIRES LINK

BATTLE PACK HIRES LINK

CRITTERS PACK HIRES LINK


POWER UP!

Pretty cool right? I think so and I'd like to ship'em to you as fast as we can. Again You pick the set or sets you'd like and you also get a 90 page DRM Free Digital sketchbook to boot! You can't lose. Plus you get to help me haggle with a few cons to get more exposure. That makes me a happy artist. As always I greatly appreciate your support and helping to make this Power Print drive a success!

FAQ

What is fulfillment time based on?

We project prints will get to anyone in the U.S. by the end of November. This is based on time it takes to get the money from Indiegogo, printing time and shipping times. International pledges will take longer to travel but should be shipped in time for the holidays.

What if my prints come damaged?

DO NOT OPEN YOU PACKAGE if they arrive damaged. Bring the package to the Post Office and open it in front of an agent. Outer damage to the package doesn't necessarily mean the prints will be damaged inside but if they are this helps speed up your claim process when they see you open the package. We are not responsible for any shipping damage and you can check our youtube page to see a video of how the prints are packaged. USPS provides $50 of insurance included with Priority Mail and for the higher tiers extra insurance will be covered

Are they signed by the artist?

Yes. I sign all the prints after they get printed then my business partner Josh handles all the packaging, shipping and customer service.

Are shipping costs included?

Shipping to the U.S. is included for international please contact us.

story:
HELLO

My name is Derek Housh and I am a senior film student at Cal State University Monterey Bay. Everyone Dies In A Car Crash is my senior thesis film and is an experimental short film (estimated 5 minutes) about a man who performs at an open mic to an empty theater of manikins just moments after dying in a car crash. He tells several stories that visually will be represented through experimenting with polaroid manipulation, super 8 film, 16mm film, beta, HD DVC, exposure, and colors. The entire film is narrated and manipulated by the sounds playing from a changing radio station. 

WHY I WANT TO MAKE THIS FILM.

I want to make this film because I feel that I have something to say and present to the world. I believe that I have a thorough understanding of the responsibilities of one labeling themselves as both a filmmaker and an artist, and the importance of being truthful with both yourself and with the work you create. This film will be the grand finale to my college undergraduate studies where for the four last years I have worked hard to get to where I am now as an artist.

WHAT I NEED YOUR HELP FOR

I plan on shooting much of this on film, both super 8 and 16mm. Film is pretty expensive, I have shot on 8mm and 16mm several times before and have been shooting 35mm stills for the past 5 years. The cost of all the film to bought, developed, and trasnfered will be around 800 dollars. I believe that shooting on film is worth the trouble though and I am willing to work harder with your support on making a quality film. I also need to rent out the Golden State Theater for a few hours which will cost 350 dollars. I will need to pay for gas for actors and crew, part of the film we will have to drive to San Louis Obispo to shoot. The actors and crew will have to be fed too.

I am doing my best at trying to keep cost low and purposely wrote a script that I felt that I could properly shoot based off of the knowledge of filmmaking techniques that I have come to learn over my entire college career. I feel that I have a very clear image that I want to create with this film and I feel confident that I can achieve my goal with the support of the community.  

Some hopefully convincing points on why you should donate.

I am proud to say that I have a very talented and creative crew for this project as both Estoy Suerte and Jordan Rodriguez will be helping me to make this film happen. 

Jordan is an extremely talented experimental visual artist, and has the roleof Director of Photography on this project.

The entire film's sound design will be written and recorded by the Artist Estoy Suerte (Frankie Botello) and myself. I have worked extremely close with Estoy Suerte for all of college and have already made numerous films and projects with him. 

Here are some links to some of my work.

http://www.youtube.com/user/HoushFilms

https://soundcloud.com/publicoutburst   (I release music under the name TAJ.) 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TTs9efJzIWs&list=UU8EKh7_3jMiRKE5xq9_-sbQ&feature=c4-overview        (This is a short film that I shot on Super 8 and HD DVC. Estoy Suerte composed the music for it)

http://derekhoush.tumblr.com/


Academics and Achievements

At the end of this semester I will be graduating with a Bachelor of The Arts from the Cinematic Arts Department from Cal State University Monterey Bay.

I had an internship with HARA Motion Pictures where I studied under and worked for Mike Buffo for almost 7 months starting in January of 2013. I worked mainly as an editor and color corrections, but occasionally worked as a freelance videographer for events or projects through HARA. Mike taught me a lot of technical aspects to filmmaking that has helped immensely with my ability to put ideas into reality, and I feel that much of my creative technical strengths have much to do with the encouragement I got from HARA Motion Pictures.

I have had many major roles on numerous other short films and senior thesis films while studying at CSUMB. Several have gone off to film festivals and even won some awards and landed a spot on IMBD. 

I have created my own series of music and sound related videos within the internet video community that I have titled Public Outburst Sessions. I have released over thirty projects under this title in the past two years. Some of which were shot on film.

I worked mainly as an editor and color corrections, but occasionally worked as a freelance videographer for events or projects through HARA. Mike taught me a lot of technical aspects to filmmaking that has helped immensely with my ability to put ideas into reality, and I feel that much of my creative technical strengths have much to do with the encouragement I got from HARA Motion Pictures.I have had many major roles on numerous other short films and senior thesis films while studying at CSUMB. Several have gone off to film festivals and even won some awards and landed a spot on IMBD. I have created my own series of music and sound related videos within the internet video community that I have titled Public Outburst Sessions. I have released over thirty projects under this title in the past two years. Some of which were shot on film.

story:
STATUS UPDATES!

8/6 - URGENT!  There are only five days left in the campaign and we need your help!  

With the existing donations, we have been able to make some necessary infrastructure adjustments and upgrade Atlas, but we need to reach $2,500 by 3 PM Sunday 8/7 to complete the third tree and canopy structure. 

This is a photo of the third tree in progress!  Partially assembled tricycle for scale.

Here's an image of the canopy skeleton suspended by a crane at American Steel!

Once complete, hitting the following goals will let us finish the project:

  • An additional $1,000 to purchase the full scale canopy LEDs, wire, and integrate them into the movement reactive system
  • $1,500 more to  get all of this hard work to the Playa, and get it placed front and center at 6:45 and Esplanade for everyone to enjoy
  • Everything above $5,000 will help us expand the sound and lights even further, for an enhanced experience!

As artists, we seek to inspire and extol all that is beautifully human. To create not just aesthetically pleasing things or sounds, but to create spaces where art, technology, and human interactions come together into experiences that celebrate individuality, allow folks to find connection, build community, and foster understanding. It's a labor of love. And while done from a place of love, make no mistake - building these experiences is indeed labor...long hours, late nights...with little to no reward other than knowing we were able to make some people happy.  We hope experiencing this will add to your experience at the Burn this year!

Thank you so much for your support, and see you in the dust!!

====== )'( ======

What is Arborealis Forest?

The forest is comprised of three primary components:  three metallic tree structures, a sound/motion system, and a reactive led canopy.  These components are controlled by a hardware and software system dubbed "Atlas".

The goal is to build an interactive environmental multi-sensory art installation that incorporates many different elements together to create a life changing experience for its visitors.  The movement of these visitors within the forest affect the sound and visuals the installation produces, creating a space that is ever changing and alive.

The Trees
The three sculptures of metal trees form a diameter of 15-20 feet, with exposed root systems below and a canopy above that expands from the highest branches.  The base of each tree is shaped in octagonal rings.  Each trunk is 4 feet in diameter, staked to a height of 15 feet and reinforced vertically.  Donated / recycled steel makes up the base and infrastructure of each tree.

The Sound and Motion Detection System
Four surround speakers are placed between the trees, creating the surround sound that fills the participants' space.  Each of the speakers reside inside designed mushroom sculptures for an optimal aural experience.  The sound system controllers and mixers are placed in the middle of the space between the trees inside a beautiful sculpture named ATLAS.

ATLAS is the main computer system which controls the sound system, cameras, sensors, and lights in the canopy.  A semi-transparent half-dome covers the "head" of ATLAS, while the body is built from steel and copper.

The Canopy
The canopy has been designed to replicate "Tree of Life" geometry, and will be formed by intersecting and connected branches made of steel beams secured and reinforced with connectors and bolts that emerge from the three tree trunks.  A net of LED lights will be suspended from the tree's uppermost branches and will display sound reactive LED effects.

Imagine a cold night on the playa:  you've recently bought the $25 heart to heart hug perk and are about to be engulfed in a warm faux-fur embrace as the lights of the canopy sparkle around you.  A cavorting whirl of revelers dance around the trees, entering sound zones and triggering a symphony of sounds and illumination, delighting your senses.

 

OUR VISION

We developed and created this project with a clear goal in mind:  To create a place where art technology, human interactions and connections all come together to create new shared experiences enhancing those bonds through music, visuals and shared activity.

 

WHO WE ARE

We are artists, makers, producers, musicians, organizers, party throwers, and high functioning party animals (HFPAs™).  We're a crew of veteran burners who love to create with and for our community.  Our community is your community, and we welcome you to Get Involved!

We’ve actualized art projects big and small, manifested beauty, lead camps, crafted art cars, engineered music, bounced dance floors, programmed machines, and subversively reclaimed technology for good. Projects and experiences our crew members have built include the Airpusher Art Car, Alien Siege Machine. Cuttlefish. Dancy Dance. Icarus. Sacred and Propane. Quantum Entanglement.  The Kraken.  The Playa Surfer motorized surfboards and many more.

WHERE WILL YOUR DONATION GO?

  • New Canopy - A net of LED lights designed and based on “The Tree of Life” design resides above the participant's head and displays sound reactive LED effects.  The image below shows a birds eye view of the canopy design as placed above the trees.

  • Build Tree Number 3 , and organic design following the steps of our previous 2 other trees to complete our forest and the user experience

  • Improved new sound system and interaction for better more impressive user experience
  • Truck rental for transport of the artwork to and from the Playa!

 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to reach our goal, we need to raise a total of at least $5,000 USD, and we hope you can help us get there!  There are several different donation tiers which will get you different perks in return.  Please donate!

Sticker Design

Polymer Necklace Canopy Medallion

Reclaimed Red Oak Necklace Canopy Medallion

Shirts - Image on Back

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help!  Please get the word out to your friends, community, burning man camp, and anyone you think may be interested in supporting art.

 

FAQ

Are you a non-profit?  Can I write-off my contribution with my taxes?
Yes, Arborealis is registered as a public 501(c)(3) nonprofit, as part of the American Society Supporting Community Art Projects. Contributions to Arborealis are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.  The American Society Supporting Community Art Projects EIN is 46-5739041.

How can I get a tax deductible receipt?
When you contribute, you will receive an email from FirstGiving (Indiegogo’s nonprofit payments processor) confirming your contribution.  This email receipt can be used for tax deductible purposes. For all contributions over $250, you will receive an official receipt for tax-reporting purposes by email after the the campaign ends.

How will the funds be used?
The funds will be used to complete the following:

  • Build Third Tree
  • Design and Build Canopy
  • Upgrade Sound System
  • Transport to and From Burning Man 2016

Can I donate from outside the USA?
Absolutely! Indiegogo only accepts international credit cards, not bank or debit cards. Unfortunately we can’t accept PayPal, so the way to donate internationally is with a credit card.

Is shipping included?
Yes! 

Does international shipping cost extra?
Yes, these costs will automatically be appended if you select shipping outside of the United States.

I have more questions. Who do I ask?
Learn More: http://www.arborealisforest.com/
Keep Updated: https://www.facebook.com/Arborealisforest/?fref=ts
Get Involved: Arborealisforest@gmail.com

story:
Our Project

Debbie here.  My 50-minute play, Jane Bald: A Ghost Story, will appear in the Emerging Artist Theatre's New Work Series on Friday, May 29th.  Many of my Tennessee friends have no doubt stood atop Jane Bald, and I'm so excited to bring this piece of the Appalachian Trail to NYC.  

I am further delighted that Jim Knipple will be directing, and he's brought on board incredibly talented actors Janel Miley (Jean Machine), Landon Green (Soul Flute), and Stacey Weckstein (Jane).  Most of these artists are coming in from the mountains of West Virginia, but to bring these Appalachian artists to the Big Apple, we need a little support - and that's where you come in.  


What We Need

To make this production a success - and to make sure that my artists don't experience any financial hardship - it's important that our production have a few things: 

  • Funds to cover travel expenses.  We'll be traveling on a shoestring budget, but we'll still need money to cover gas, food, and metro rides.
  • Basic props and set pieces.  Though this is a workshop production, we want it to be as professional and beautiful as possible, so we will likely need to make a few properties purchases. 
  • Publicity.  Again, our advertising budget is totally shoestring and mostly consists of my printing out flyers on a LaserJet.  But ink, guys.  Ink is pricey.
  • An Audience!  Emerging Artist Theatre asks us to guarantee one audience member for every minute of our show.  But much more importantly, we want to fill the house so that we can provide a great night of theatre to as many people as possible.
We would love it if you would make a monetary contribution, but getting the word out is even more important.  So whether or not you are able to make a donation, spreading the word about our production to your New York/New England/New Jersey/wherever friends helps us just as much as cash ever could. 

Why should I give? 

Obviously, many of you who are reading this are our friends, colleagues, and fellow artists.  If you can't attend the show, even a very small donation is a great way to lend us moral support - and we can't thank you enough for all the other ways you support us in our day to day lives. 

In addition, by supporting this project, you support working artists and emerging, creative theatre beyond the bounds of Broadway.  You also support Appalachian art and the success of regional works on the national stage. 

Thank you for your enthusiasm, for spreading the word, and for your contribution!

story:
Check out our 2015 Official Festival Preview!


WITHOUT YOUR SUPPORT, WE RISK LOSING OUR 4TH ANNUAL HUMAN RIGHTS FILM FESTIVAL

In 2012, we had a eureka moment when we discovered that art was the best way to raise awareness of human rights stories and we launched our first ever Human Rights Film Festival in downtown Toronto. Each year, our Festival has grown by leaps and bounds, attracting more audience members, while collaborating with more partners and changemakers to provide a platform for people to share their human rights stories through the arts. In 2014 we had 19 Films, 13 Premieres, 21 Community Partners, 16 Countries in Focus, 1,380 Attendees, nearly triple the amount since we launched in 2012.

Everything was going according to plan for our 4th annual Film Festival when at the last minute one of our major backers had to unexpectedly pull out. We were completely blindsided, but we are determined to pull this off. This is why we need your help.

With your support, 2015 is going to be our biggest year yet, with our film festival expanding an extra day, a bigger venue to screen in (The Bloor Hot Docs Cinema) and bigger audiences. Your backing will help important human rights films and discussions gain an audience in Toronto and create the kinds of spaces necessary to explore and imagine a better and more just world for everyone. 

Human rights stories are everywhere.

Our world is full of human rights stories. On a trip to North Korea in 2008, I began to learn about the horrific injustices that were affecting an entire nation: modern day concentration camps, a famine that took the lives of millions and much more. I became obsessed with not just learning more about these stories but trying to share them with as many people as I could. My mission was to get people to care as much as I did because if positive social change were to ever happen, people had to be aware that there was an issue there in the first place. And more often than not, it didn't work.

How art can change the world.  


All of that changed by chance when I saw the power of a documentary film on North Korea convince a group of people in a room to care. This is when I learned that art was the best way to get through to people. Art is accessible, can build empathy, take us to new places and most importantly, create an environment and safe place where people can come together to engage in the kinds of dialogue that are necessary for positive social change. 

With this knowledge, I immediately assembled a team of passionate individuals in 2012 including artists, human rights advocates, and people with film festival experience and launched our first ever Human Rights Film Festival in 2012. And it was a huge success! Just check out the growth: 

  • 2012 FILM FESTIVAL: 7 Films, 1 Premiere, 5 Community Partners, 1 Country in Focus, 560 Attendance 
  • 2013 FILM FESTIVAL: 9 Films, 3 Premieres, 7 Community Partners, 1 Country in Focus, 790 Attendance 
  • 2014 FILM FESTIVAL: 19 Films, 13 Premieres, 21 Community Partners, 16 Countries in Focus, 1,380 Attendance


Since then, our mission has brought us to nearly a dozen schools and students across North America, several national and international media outlets, and even the United Nations Human Rights Assembly in Geneva. Most importantly, we’ve been able to share human rights stories with tens of thousands of people and continue to see our mission grow and reach new communities each year. 

We Need Your Support to Continue Sharing Human Rights Stories!  

Despite all of these successes, we risk losing our 4th Annual Human Rights Film Festival from December 10-13, 2015 due to lost funding that was beyond our control. We learned in late October that we lost our Lead Sponsor due to budgeting cuts on their end and this has left us with a huge hole to fill. Without the support of our community, we face the harsh reality that there may not be a Film Festival this December. 

The good news? We’re a team of very dedicated individuals (read below), our network continues to grow year after year, and we’re confident that with your support, we’ll be able to reach our $15,000 goal.  

Beyond Film: We Do So Much More! 

We are so much more than just a Human Rights Film Festival and in 2015, we were so proud to launch and expand on three new programs. This speaks to our incredible potential and growth. These programs include: 

  • JAYU Speaks: launched in late 2014, this monthly speaker series provides the platform for local artists, and individuals to share their local human rights stories. To date, we've held 11 events focusing on issues like: refugees, institutionalized racism, women's rights, security certificates, and much more. We've invited nearly 50 guests to share their stories with more than 400 audience members. 
  • The Hum Podcast: Even in silence, there is always a hum in the background but you often only notice it if you're paying attention. The Hum is a metaphor for human rights stories all around us: we only notice them if we want to. This podcast will rebrand the way we talk about human rights. Hosted by award-winning documentary filmmaker Amar Wala, and Gilad Cohen, The Hum will launch in 2015/2016. 
  • Photography Mentorship Program / #CaptureTheStreets: In 2015, we collaborated with six very talented local photographers (@SoTeeOh, @chinpua, @tahaphoto, @g_wah, @gummyting, @normster), Community Story Strategies, and Horizons for Youth and provided the mentorship and safe space where the youth participants became empowered to share their artwork and personal stories through photography. We displayed the participant's best photos in three rotating galleries across Toronto, attracting more than 1,500 people and raising more than $4,000, with 100% of the profits going back to the youth. 

Our Stretch Goals.

Why continuing to support us if we surpass our $15,000 goal is so important. 

If we reach our $15,000 goal, we don't want the support to stop! With additional donations, we'll be able to do even more in 2016 including: 

  • Mentoring even more communities through the arts: We hope to collaborate with more artists, organizations and changemakers to provide safe spaces and mentorship where we can empower even more at-risk and marginalized communities through the arts. We want to take the lessons and successes we gained from our 2015 Photography Mentorship Program and do the project all over again with communities all across the province in places like Thunder Bay, Windsor, Ottawa and more! 
  • Supporting and expanding our existing platforms: With additional support, you'll help ensure that we can provide the spaces necessary to engage our community in dialogue through our JAYU Speaks and The Hum programs. 
  • A year-round presence: We're dedicated, passionate and we love what we do! We believe so strongly in JAYU's mission that we want to make sure we continue to have a year-round presence in our community. Your support will help ensure that we can do just that! 

We're the right people! 

Our Accomplishments:
Since we launched in 2012, we've won numerous awards and have been invited to participate and speak on numerous platforms including: 
  • Speaking at the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva in 2012. 
  • Winning the award for Most Innovative Project at Humber College's Innovation Fair in 2014 for the Photography Mentorship Program. 
  • Being selected as one of thirty Rothschild Fellows in 2015 at Cambridge University.
  • Invited to speak on numerous media platforms including: CTV, Globe & Mail, Al Jazeera America, CBC, and much more.

Between our staff, Board of Directors, and year-round volunteers, more than 15,000 hours are dedicated to making sure crucial awareness is raised. 

It speaks to the dedication of our team that we have managed to accomplish so much in so little time. Moreover, it speaks to our potential. JAYU has drawn exclusively on the efforts of volunteers who have managed to juggle the demands of full-time careers with their passion for a worthy cause. Imagine what we could accomplish were we able to give JAYU a year-round presence. If we could donate the hours we give to our careers directly to JAYU it is not being overly optimistic to envision our impact becoming global. Imagine what that means for those whose stories we haven’t heard, for those waiting in need of such an outlet. To turn JAYU from a volunteer-based organization to a permanent one is to ensure a permanent platform for those who need to share their stories.

Some of our team includes: 

GILAD COHEN, FOUNDER / EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR
Gilad is an artist, human rights advocate and founder of Jayu, a non-profit that uses art to share human rights stories. Gilad has been actively involved in the human rights scene since 2006. Feeling the need to raise more awareness in his own community, Gilad launched Jayu in 2012, using art as the main vehicle. Gilad has been invited to speak on human rights in media and several platforms including CTV, CBC, The Globe and Mail, Al Jazeera America, and the 19th session of the UN Human Rights Council meeting in Geneva in 2012. In 2015, he was selected as Rothschild Fellow through The University of Cambridge in the UK.

ALICKS GIROWSKI, DIRECTOR OF OPERATIONS
Alicks Girowski is a skilled professional with ten years of event and volunteer management.  She helped launch the London Ontario Live Arts Festival (LOLA) in 2006, where she served as  Administrator/ General Manager from 2006-10 and aided in the development and management of numerous organizations.  Alicks Girowski is currently the Volunteer Manager at Hot Docs, North America's largest documentary film festival. Since her move to Toronto in 2010, Alicks has been part has recruited, trained and supervised over 2,300 volunteers annually.  

DAVID VELLA, BOARD CHAIR

In 2001, David Vella joined the Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF) as Director of Major Gifts and moved into his current position as Director of Board and Executive Relations in 2006, managing the TIFF Board of Directors, their committees, and TIFF’s senior staff. From 2002 to 2010, David also worked on the design and construction of TIFF Bell Lightbox. Prior to TIFF, David worked at the University of Toronto as the Senior Development Officer for three of UofT’s colleges (1997 – 2001) and in various fundraising roles with the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation (1991- 1997). David also chaired the board of Inside Out, an LGBT group who, among other things, annually hosts the Inside Out Film Festival in both Toronto and Ottawa. He has also sat on the board of the Volcano Theatre Company and the advisory board of the Canadian Sports Film Festival. 


JACK KIM, BOARD MEMBER

Jack is the founder and former executive director of HanVoice, the largest organization in Canada advocating on behalf of North Korean human rights and refugees. Jack has spoken about the North Korean human rights issue to audiences across Canada. Jack has also been called on to comment on North Korean affairs by both Members of Parliament and cabinet and has also appeared in media such as the CBC, CTV, Global News, the National Post, the Toronto Star, the Korea Times, YTN and Radio Free Asia. 

Rewards.

We've got great rewards including our Official Jayu Cap, discounted tickets and incredible access to our Film Festival, hotel stays, dinner with guests and filmmakers, autographed movies and film stills, and much, much more. 

About JAYU.

JAYU (자유): noun // free·dom // ˈfrēdəm

Founded in 2012, JAYU is a registered Canadian non-profit organization that shares human rights stories through the arts.

Everything was going according to plan for our 4th annual Film Festival when at the last minute one of our major backers had to unexpectedly pull out. We were completely blindsided, but we are determined to pull this off. This is why we need your help.With your support, 2015 is going to be our biggest year yet, with our film festival expanding an extra day, a bigger venue to screen in (The Bloor Hot Docs Cinema) and bigger audiences. Your backing will help important human rights films and discussions gain an audience in Toronto and create the kinds of spaces necessary to explore and imagine a better and more just world for everyone. 

Human rights stories are everywhere.

Our world is full of human rights stories. On a trip to North Korea in 2008, I began to learn about the horrific injustices that were affecting an entire nation: modern day concentration camps, a famine that took the lives of millions and much more. I became obsessed with not just learning more about these stories but trying to share them with as many people as I could. My mission was to get people to care as much as I did because if positive social change were to ever happen, people had to be aware that there was an issue there in the first place. And more often than not, it didn't work.

How art can change the world.  



All of that changed by chance when I saw the power of a documentary film on North Korea convince a group of people in a room to care. This is when I learned that art was the best way to get through to people. Art is accessible, can build empathy, take us to new places and most importantly, create an environment and safe place where people can come together to engage in the kinds of dialogue that are necessary for positive social change. 
With this knowledge, I immediately assembled a team of passionate individuals in 2012 including artists, human rights advocates, and people with film festival experience and launched our first ever Human Rights Film Festival in 2012. And it was a huge success! Just check out the growth: 

2012 FILM FESTIVAL: 7 Films, 1 Premiere, 5 Community Partners, 1 Country in Focus, 560 Attendance 

2013 FILM FESTIVAL: 9 Films, 3 Premieres, 7 Community Partners, 1 Country in Focus, 790 Attendance 

2014 FILM FESTIVAL: 19 Films, 13 Premieres, 21 Community Partners, 16 Countries in Focus, 1,380 Attendance

Since then, our mission has brought us to nearly a dozen schools and students across North America, several national and international media outlets, and even the United Nations Human Rights Assembly in Geneva. Most importantly, we’ve been able to share human rights stories with tens of thousands of people and continue to see our mission grow and reach new communities each year. 
We Need Your Support to Continue Sharing Human Rights Stories!  

Despite all of these successes, we risk losing our 4th Annual Human Rights Film Festival from December 10-13, 2015 due to lost funding that was beyond our control. We learned in late October that we lost our Lead Sponsor due to budgeting cuts on their end and this has left us with a huge hole to fill. Without the support of our community, we face the harsh reality that there may not be a Film Festival this December. 
The good news? We’re a team of very dedicated individuals (read below), our network continues to grow year after year, and we’re confident that with your support, we’ll be able to reach our $15,000 goal.  
Beyond Film: We Do So Much More! 

We are so much more than just a Human Rights Film Festival and in 2015, we were so proud to launch and expand on three new programs. This speaks to our incredible potential and growth. These programs include: 
JAYU Speaks: launched in late 2014, this monthly speaker series provides the platform for local artists, and individuals to share their local human rights stories. To date, we've held 11 events focusing on issues like: refugees, institutionalized racism, women's rights, security certificates, and much more. We've invited nearly 50 guests to share their stories with more than 400 audience members. 

The Hum Podcast: Even in silence, there is always a hum in the background but you often only notice it if you're paying attention. The Hum is a metaphor for human rights stories all around us: we only notice them if we want to. This podcast will rebrand the way we talk about human rights. Hosted by award-winning documentary filmmaker Amar Wala, and Gilad Cohen, The Hum will launch in 2015/2016. 

Photography Mentorship Program / #CaptureTheStreets: In 2015, we collaborated with six very talented local photographers (@SoTeeOh, @chinpua, @tahaphoto, @g_wah, @gummyting, @normster), Community Story Strategies, and Horizons for Youth and provided the mentorship and safe space where the youth participants became empowered to share their artwork and personal stories through photography. We displayed the participant's best photos in three rotating galleries across Toronto, attracting more than 1,500 people and raising more than $4,000, with 100% of the profits going back to the youth. 
Our Stretch Goals.


Why continuing to support us if we surpass our $15,000 goal is so important. 


If we reach our $15,000 goal, we don't want the support to stop! With additional donations, we'll be able to do even more in 2016 including: Mentoring even more communities through the arts: We hope to collaborate with more artists, organizations and changemakers to provide safe spaces and mentorship where we can empower even more at-risk and marginalized communities through the arts. We want to take the lessons and successes we gained from our 2015 Photography Mentorship Program and do the project all over again with communities all across the province in places like Thunder Bay, Windsor, Ottawa and more! 

Supporting and expanding our existing platforms: With additional support, you'll help ensure that we can provide the spaces necessary to engage our community in dialogue through our JAYU Speaks and The Hum programs. 

A year-round presence: We're dedicated, passionate and we love what we do! We believe so strongly in JAYU's mission that we want to make sure we continue to have a year-round presence in our community. Your support will help ensure that we can do just that! 

We're the right people! 

Our Accomplishments:Since we launched in 2012, we've won numerous awards and have been invited to participate and speak on numerous platforms including: Speaking at the United Nations Human Rights Council in Geneva in 2012. 
Winning the award for Most Innovative Project at Humber College's Innovation Fair in 2014 for the Photography Mentorship Program. 
Being selected as one of thirty Rothschild Fellows in 2015 at Cambridge University.
Invited to speak on numerous media platforms including: CTV, Globe & Mail, Al Jazeera America, CBC, and much more.

Between our staff, Board of Directors, and year-round volunteers, more than 15,000 hours are dedicated to making sure crucial awareness is raised. 
It speaks to the dedication of our team that we have managed to accomplish so much in so little time. Moreover, it speaks to our potential. JAYU has drawn exclusively on the efforts of volunteers who have managed to juggle the demands of full-time careers with their passion for a worthy cause. Imagine what we could accomplish were we able to give JAYU a year-round presence. If we could donate the hours we give to our careers directly to JAYU it is not being overly optimistic to envision our impact becoming global. Imagine what that means for those whose stories we haven’t heard, for those waiting in need of such an outlet. To turn JAYU from a volunteer-based organization to a permanent one is to ensure a permanent platform for those who need to share their stories.Some of our team includes: 

GILAD COHEN, FOUNDER / EXECUTIVE DIRECTORGilad is an artist, human rights advocate and founder of Jayu, a non-profit that uses art to share human rights stories. Gilad has been actively involved in the human rights scene since 2006. Feeling the need to raise more awareness in his own community, Gilad launched Jayu in 2012, using art as the main vehicle. Gilad has been invited to speak on human rights in media and several platforms including CTV, CBC, The Globe and Mail, Al Jazeera America, and the 19th session of the UN Human Rights Council meeting in Geneva in 2012. In 2015, he was selected as Rothschild Fellow through The University of Cambridge in the UK.
ALICKS GIROWSKI, DIRECTOR OF OPERATIONSAlicks Girowski is a skilled professional with ten years of event and volunteer management.  She helped launch the London Ontario Live Arts Festival (LOLA) in 2006, where she served as  Administrator/ General Manager from 2006-10 and aided in the development and management of numerous organizations.  Alicks Girowski is currently the Volunteer Manager at Hot Docs, North America's largest documentary film festival. Since her move to Toronto in 2010, Alicks has been part has recruited, trained and supervised over 2,300 volunteers annually.  DAVID VELLA, BOARD CHAIR




In 2001, David Vella joined the Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF) as Director of Major
Gifts and moved into his current position as Director of Board and Executive Relations in 2006,
managing the TIFF Board of Directors, their committees, and TIFF’s senior staff. From 2002 to
2010, David also worked on the design and construction of TIFF Bell Lightbox. Prior to TIFF,
David worked at the University of Toronto as the Senior Development Officer for three of UofT’s
colleges (1997 – 2001) and in various fundraising roles with the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation (1991-
1997). David also chaired the board of Inside Out, an LGBT group who, among other things,
annually hosts the Inside Out Film Festival in both Toronto and Ottawa. He has also sat on the board
of the Volcano Theatre Company and the advisory board of the Canadian Sports Film Festival. 


JACK KIM, BOARD MEMBER




Jack is the founder and former executive director of HanVoice, the largest organization in Canada
advocating on behalf of North Korean human rights and refugees. Jack has spoken about the North Korean human rights issue to audiences across Canada. Jack has
also been called on to comment on North Korean affairs by both Members of Parliament and
cabinet and has also appeared in media such as the CBC, CTV, Global News, the National Post, the
Toronto Star, the Korea Times, YTN and Radio Free Asia. 



Rewards.
We've got great rewards including our Official Jayu Cap, discounted tickets and incredible access to our Film Festival, hotel stays, dinner with guests and filmmakers, autographed movies and film stills, and much, much more. 

About JAYU.


JAYU (자유): noun // free·dom // ˈfrēdəm
Founded in 2012, JAYU is a registered Canadian non-profit organization that shares human rights stories through the arts.

story:
Who Am I?

I am a traditional watercolor artist who really enjoys making things like stickers and greeting cards that anyone can enjoy. I launched a shop on Etsy last year and have enjoyed creating new and fun items to sell. I have started selling stickers that contain my art. The problem is that once I have printed my stickers I then have to cut to cut them out by hand. 

 

What's The Money for?

My goal is to raise enough money to buy an electric cutting machine that would give me the ability to make perfect cuts for my stickers. This would take the sticker collections I sell to a more professional level.  The machine I have my eye on is the Brother ScanNCut Machine (Cost approx. $650 plus tax, plus shipping). It is one of the more pricier machines but has features I feel would greatly benefit my small art business. 

 

What Do You Get?

I so greatly appreciate your support. I am setting my start goal at $300 which will cover less than half the cost of the machine. If I reach my goal, everyone who has backed the project will receive:

  • 5 sheets of stickers ($10* contribution gets you $25 worth of stickers) designed by me!

If I manage to double my goal then I will double the amount of stickers that go out. $600 means everyone who backs this project will now get:

  • 10 different sheets of stickers (that's $50 worth of stickers for each $10* contribution).  

If we manage to hit $900, I will send out even more stickers to every pledger!

* Funds are in Canadian dollars. Dollar amount might appear less depending on your country.

 

 

When will you get your stickers?

Assuming we reach the goal, I will be sending out stickers in October. Please be aware that some countries do take longer to ship to than others. The United States in particular has been experiencing extreme delays. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, and that's ok! Here is how you can still help:

  • Help get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools to make it easy to help spread the word.

If you are have contributed, get more out of your contribution by sharing and increasing our goal.

story:
Short Summary

Healing the Warrior Heart is a Movement led by Andrew R. Jones, Marine Corps Combat Veteran, to reach out to veterans and their family members to help them achieve a sense of peace and healing by using creative outlets and spiritual faith.

What We Need

We need $1,000 to purchase and print a large amount of t-shirts to sell and give away at community functions to help raise money for the movement as well as help raise awareness about the current issues affecting our veterans and their family members. 

The Impact

The impact of your monetary contribution is massive.  With each dollar, we are closer to reaching our goal and getting plenty of shirts made.  The sales of the shirts will go towards the forward movement of the campaign and when possible, the shirts will be donated at community events.

story:
Background

Joshua Hart passed away tragically in a boating accident on May 17th, 2013.  He was twenty years old.  Josh was an incredibly gifted musician and artist.  We will be hosting the "For the Love of Music" fundraiser in Josh's name, but if you can't make the event in person, please consider contributing to this campaign.  

Your Impact

  • All proceeds will be donated directly to the Rushville-Industry Art Department.
  • No amount is too small.  If 100 people donate $5 we'll meet our goal with no other donations!
  • Our goal is give the students of Rushville an art program that Josh would be proud of.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Prayer.
  • If you are unable to contribute financially, we understand.  All we ask is that you help us stir up excitement for the event.  Consider sharing it on Facebook, or writing a story about Josh on the Facebook page.

Thank you for your time, and God bless.

story:
"Click. Hello, God?"

Collaborative Multi-Disciplinary Performance Art on the themes of the plight of the modern person and the search for universal understanding of the forces behind societal and personal morality and design.

Description of event: 

A thirty minute performance art piece. Three tables will be in a studio. At the first table, a conversation between a Patient and Doctor takes place examining a variety of themes surrounding the interpretation of God, sanity, reality, and power. At the second table, The Shadow dances. At the third, a musician plays. Each of these elements will be in physical, emotional, and ideological conversation with each other as the narrative between Patient and Doctor evolves.

Description of the group: 

Three students studying theater at Cornish College of the Arts came together to create a performance. Along the way, collaborators spanning  from different artistic disciplines joined in the process that has set forth. We now have collaborators ranging in the artistic fields of not only theatre but dance, music, fine arts, design and performance production. We take this as an opportunity to manifest art that we believe in.

How can you help?

Our school has been amazing in its support and has provided a space for us to work in and a theatre for us to perform in. However, we have no funding other than our own pockets. We would love financial support from the community in order to have props, costumes, set, etc... everything that is necessary for the piece. Anything helps! Please come see the performance, and if you can't make it, we're happy to send a filmed version. (: 

Much Love, 

The Core Ensemble

story:
THE 400 Twenties Campaign for the Atlanta Rent Show

 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iYiiV96CDW0

 

Hi; my name is Ken j. Martin. I am a Singer—Songwriter/ Theater Producer/ Community Activist/ Guitar Instructor, but the title that I prefer is ARTIST. For those who don’t know me, I have been performing for over 7 years as a national touring artist fusing acoustic melodies with sultry vocals. I am humbled to have been featured on BET's Lyric Cafe, The Monique Show, and other notable venues across the United States.

Currently, I am creating 4 shows at the Southwest Performing Art Center located in Atlanta, GA for the fall theater season that deals with what I call “undiscussable topics” within diverse communities that features amazing local talent whose performances bring the stories of the everyday person to life. I have been working to make this showcase the success it has become thus far for 6 years. It has been my greatest joy to provide socially conscious artists a space where we can produce change in our communities through art. 

Your generous contribution will aid us with the last piece of financial support we will need to fully operate and sustain the project as well as the artists who are bringing this production into existence. Ultimately, we cannot allow this effort to be a fully government supported venture; the show must be supported by those who believe in our cause! We are pressing towards the mark of becoming a self-sufficient community of artists and art lovers and we need you to help us. 

We are asking for just $20 dollars from 400 people to produce $8000 which will pay for all the operational expenses to run our showcase from light and sound production to theatre space rental. The residual income from ticket sells will fund our expansion to college campuses and national festivals. Your support will help create a REAL movement! It will create a REVIVAL of art with PURPOSE from genuine people seeking change in our world by first changing the false ideas in our communities rather than fame without positive impact. 

Prizes

For those that wish to give more we have created some prizes that show our appreciation and that will allow you to support the art community beyond your monetary gift.

50 dollars will get you a ATLANTA RENT SHOW T-Shirt to wear and promote our AWESOME endeavor!

100 dollars gets you a Season Pass to the Atlanta Rent Show!

200 dollars: Season Pass for two and a T- Shirt, so that you can introduce a friend to exceptional art.

The Impact

This campaign will allow us the opportunity to reach our fundraising goals for the year. Your generous support will have catapulted starving artists to success. With your support you will allow the type of artists that you want to represent you—truth tellers and humble people with a conscious—to do so adequately. There is no other campaign on Indiegogo.com like this. I am sure of it.

 

Our Track Record

The Rent Show didn't just get to this point by luck. For 6 years we have grown into this production. From a Tea Room, to a Deli, to a Bar, to a Black Box theater, to a Community Center then to a state of the art theater. If you support us we will be all over the country in a city near you changing the world because you gave a one time gift of $20. Help us collect 400 Twenties and assist us in performing on a National scale this year.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a monetary donation simply spread the word! In 60 days we need to raise $8000.00 Please support us as we speak for you! We tell your stories! Tweet, Facebook, Google +, and email this link to at least 4 times over the next 60 days to help spread the word.

story:
Meditate to Create Program

___________________________________________________

“F@*# self-doubt. I despise it. I hold it in contempt, along with the hell-spawned ooze-pit of Resistance from which it crawled. I will NEVER back off. I will NEVER give the work anything less than 100%. If I go down in flames, so be it. I’ll be back.”

-Steven Pressfield

_______________________________________________

Mission:

Helping Others Enrich their Lives through the Simplicity of Creativity & Imagination using Meditation and Intentional Living Techniques.

How: 

Bring the Meditate to Create© Program to Title 1, Underfunded or No-Funded Art Programs at Schools, After-School Programs, Home-Schooled Children, Teachers, Business Professionals, Prisoners and Frustrated, “Stuck” Artists.

*In the process of submitting Applications for offering CEUs to Teachers & other Professional Development Courses for Various Organizations*

 

Books Currently Being Written & Developed:

“Meditate to Create: A Mystical Way to Enhancing Creativity”

 (title is subject to change)  Book/Workbook/Activity laden book with exercises and rituals to bring calmness & clarity to your life be it work, fun and quiet moments

“108 Meditate: 108 Magical Mala Moments” 

E-book/Book; an colorful inspirational & relaxing book with 108 tips on living in the moment intentionally

About the Meditate to Create© Book

In this Book You’ll Learn This & More:

  • How to Meditate
  • Meditation Techniques
  • How to get the Juices Flowing by using Meditation Techniques
  • Easy-To-Learn Basic Yoga Poses
  • How to build Practice Rituals & Building an Alter
  • The Art of Brainstorming & Mind Mapping
  • Art Lessons
  • How to Build Vision Boards or Notebooks
  • How to Find Inspiration in Everyday Activities
  • How to Light the Fire of Inspiration
  • How to Develop a Spiritual or Vision Quest 
  • How to Simplify & Develop Simplicity Skills for Every Day Living

 

*After this site is finished being built and up & running, you will receive the following after you Join the Mailing List:

*Both E-Books Complimentary!!! F R E E !!!!!

  • “Meditate to Create: A Mystical Way to Enhancing Creativity” (title is subject to change)  Book/Workbook/Activity laden book with exercises and rituals to bring calmness & clarity to your life be it work, fun and quiet moments
  • “108 Meditate: 108 Magical Mala Moments” E-book; an colorful inspirational & relaxing book with 108 tips on living in the moment intentionally

 

  • Loads of Freebies 
  • Contests & Prizes
  • Access to Online Coaching at reduced prices!
  • Guest Collaborations

 

ॐ Delve Deep into Yoga + Meditation + Love + Vision + Culture + Creation =

                                            Art/Self Expression.

 

ॐ Self-Discovery & Understanding of your Personal Mysteries & Stories.

                 Embrace, Care Deep & Grow Expansive! Be Healthy!

                _______________________________________________

Biography:

Carrie B! Cottrill, M.Ed.:  Unemployed Licenced EC-12 Art Teacher with a Diverse Background in Psychology & Art. Former Crisis Counselor & the Founder of Meditate to Create© & Intentional Living© Programs. 

I’ve taught at Several Institutions & Organizations, Hospitals, Chiropractors Offices, Eastern Michigan University, Southwest Institute of Healing Arts, Ohio University and ASU, Mesa Community College, Yoga Conference Presenter.

In 2008, I moved to a large city for an Art Teaching Position--My Dream. Even though I was teaching Art I got caught up in a very precarious situation that led me to doubt myself and lose my spirit.  If you’ve ever lost yourself or aren't living with personal SPIRIT Awareness, you know exactly what I'm talking about. In order to regain my authentic self, I had to quit my job and move back to my hometown, after falling into deep depression and falling out of touch with everyone I knew by choice.  I was doing the daily search of finding another teaching position but couldn't & haven’t.  I’m creating my DREAMS Right Here, Right Now!

So I Create:   

                                 Find & Enjoy my Bhakti Jewels

 

  

Find Your Place.       Find Yourself.       Find the Love by Giving & Receiving.

SOULFUL RECAP:

Imagine the possibilities...getting this Program to those who need the ART.

❐ Fact Sheet About the Benefits of Arts Education for Children

*Benefits of Arts Education
Source: Americans for the Arts, 2002

  • Stimulates and develops the imagination and critical thinking, and refines cognitive and creative skills.
  • Has a tremendous impact on the developmental growth of every child and has proven to help level the "learning field" across socio-economic boundaries.
  • Strengthens problem-solving and critical-thinking skills, adding to overall academic achievement and school success.
  • Develops a sense of craftsmanship, quality task performance, and goal-setting—skills needed to succeed in the classroom and beyond.
  • Teaches children life skills such as developing an informed perception; articulating a vision; learning to solve problems and make decisions; building self-confidence and self-discipline; developing the ability to imagine what might be; and accepting responsibility to complete tasks from start to finish.
  • Nurtures important values, including team-building skills; respecting alternative viewpoints; and appreciating and being aware of different cultures and traditions.

Source: Young Children and the Arts: Making Creative Connections, 1998, Introduction

  • Plays a central role in cognitive, motor, language, and social-emotional development.
  • Motivates and engages children in learning, stimulates memory, facilitates understanding, enhances symbolic communication, promotes relationships, and provides an avenue for building competence.
  • Provides a natural source of learning. Child development specialists note that play is the business of young children; play is the way children promote and enhance their development. The arts are a most natural vehicle for play.

The Need in Preschools
Source: Americans for the Arts, 2002

  • Preschool care and education, except for certain low-income programs, is considered a private service and receives little or no federal funding.
  • While the importance of early childhood arts education has received greater attention in recent years, the majority of funding and programming is directed to grades K–12, with preschools being largely underserved.
  • Arts education should not be considered a frill, but a necessity. Since preschools are not part of the public school system, funding sources vary greatly. When budgets are tight, arts programs, teachers, and supplies are often cut first.
  • More than four million children attend preschool programs nationwide.

Source: Arts Education Partnership, Children’s Learning & the Arts: Birth to Age Eight

  • Preschool-age children are primed for learning and greatly accepting of most art forms.
  • Compelling evidence exists that early arts experience has an impact on all aspects of a child’s learning and development and that, in many ways, “earlier is better.”
  • Early childhood thus presents both a unique opportunity and a unique challenge; a part of that challenge is to engage and support all who care for and educate young children in making the arts an integrated and vital part of their earliest experiences.
  • We know that "art," understood as spontaneous creative play, is what young children naturally do—singing, dancing, drawing, and role-playing. We also know that the arts engage all the senses and involve a variety of modalities including the kinesthetic, auditory, and visual. When caregivers engage and encourage children in arts activities on a regular basis from early in life, they are laying the foundation for—and even helping wire children's brains for—successful learning.

 

 I have outlined the new site to RELAX, RENEW & REJUVENATE YOU with Newletters, Activites, Interaction, Engagement, Collaboration, Feedback, Yoga/Meditation-Related Reviews, Creativity Activities, Book Reviews, Art Reviews and Sites, Ideas & Inspirations, Meditation Techniques, Zenful Habits, Soul Relationship Information & Advice from Experts...!

             LIVE IN & SPREAD THE BLISS of Calmness & Creativity

Talking about this project and sharing the link via Facebook and e-mail is a huge source of support for me and you have my utmost gratitude for spreading the word.

Carrie B!
story_txt:
Meditate to Create Program
___________________________________________________
“F@*# self-doubt. I despise it. I hold it in contempt, along with the hell-spawned ooze-pit of Resistance from which it crawled. I will NEVER back off. I will NEVER give the work anything less than 100%. If I go down in flames, so be it. I’ll be back.” 
-Steven Pressfield
_______________________________________________
Mission:
Helping Others Enrich their Lives through the Simplicity of Creativity & Imagination using Meditation and Intentional Living Techniques.
How: 
Bring the Meditate to Create© Program to Title 1, Underfunded or No-Funded Art Programs at Schools, After-School Programs, Home-Schooled Children, Teachers, Business Professionals, Prisoners and Frustrated, “Stuck” Artists.
*In the process of submitting Applications for offering CEUs to Teachers & other Professional Development Courses for Various Organizations*
 
Books Currently Being Written & Developed:
“Meditate to Create: A Mystical Way to Enhancing Creativity”
 (title is subject to change)  Book/Workbook/Activity laden book with exercises and rituals to bring calmness & clarity to your life be it work, fun and quiet moments
“108 Meditate: 108 Magical Mala Moments” 
E-book/Book; an colorful inspirational & relaxing book with 108 tips on living in the moment intentionally
About the Meditate to Create© Book
In this Book You’ll Learn This & More:

How to Meditate
Meditation Techniques
How to get the Juices Flowing by using Meditation Techniques
Easy-To-Learn Basic Yoga Poses
How to build Practice Rituals & Building an Alter
The Art of Brainstorming & Mind Mapping
Art Lessons
How to Build Vision Boards or Notebooks
How to Find Inspiration in Everyday Activities
How to Light the Fire of Inspiration
How to Develop a Spiritual or Vision Quest 
How to Simplify & Develop Simplicity Skills for Every Day Living
 
*After this site is finished being built and up & running, you will receive the following after you Join the Mailing List:
*Both E-Books Complimentary!!! F R E E !!!!!

“Meditate to Create: A Mystical Way to Enhancing Creativity” (title is subject to change)  Book/Workbook/Activity laden book with exercises and rituals to bring calmness & clarity to your life be it work, fun and quiet moments
“108 Meditate: 108 Magical Mala Moments” E-book; an colorful inspirational & relaxing book with 108 tips on living in the moment intentionally
 

Loads of Freebies 
Contests & Prizes
Access to Online Coaching at reduced prices!
Guest Collaborations
 

ॐ Delve Deep into Yoga + Meditation + Love + Vision + Culture + Creation =
                                            Art/Self Expression.
 
ॐ Self-Discovery & Understanding of your Personal Mysteries & Stories.
                 Embrace, Care Deep & Grow Expansive! Be Healthy!
                _______________________________________________
Biography:
Carrie B! Cottrill, M.Ed.:  Unemployed Licenced EC-12 Art Teacher with a Diverse Background in Psychology & Art. Former Crisis Counselor & the Founder of Meditate to Create© & Intentional Living© Programs. 
I’ve taught at Several Institutions & Organizations, Hospitals, Chiropractors Offices, Eastern Michigan University, Southwest Institute of Healing Arts, Ohio University and ASU, Mesa Community College, Yoga Conference Presenter.
In 2008, I moved to a large city for an Art Teaching Position--My Dream. Even though I was teaching Art I got caught up in a very precarious situation that led me to doubt myself and lose my spirit.  If you’ve ever lost yourself or aren't living with personal SPIRIT Awareness, you know exactly what I'm talking about. In order to regain my authentic self, I had to quit my job and move back to my hometown, after falling into deep depression and falling out of touch with everyone I knew by choice.  I was doing the daily search of finding another teaching position but couldn't & haven’t.  I’m creating my DREAMS Right Here, Right Now!
So I Create:   
                                 Find & Enjoy my Bhakti Jewels
 

  
Find Your Place.       Find Yourself.       Find the Love by Giving & Receiving.
        Find the Lust.              Find Self Love.           Find Your Creative Spirit.
Find Happiness & Peace and Spread IT!

story:
The Project

In Spring 2017, North Wales will host "Fragments from Syria" a unique collection  of contemporary Syrian art, collated in partnership by Syria.Art and Dr Zigs/Bubbles Not Bombs.

The week-long exhibition in Bangor, Gwynedd, will feature fine art in various forms, reflecting the diversity and creativity of Syrian artists at work in 2017. 

The event will promote artists still resident in Syria, as well as those among the diaspora, providing them with a unique, shared platform from which their work will engage with local, national and international audiences. 

The featured work will provoke discourse of the current affairs in Syria, as well as explorations of the power of art in healing, and of culture as being of vital importance in times of chaos. The collection is sure to provide an enriched understanding and appreciation among the public of the artistic heritage within Syria, reflected in these contemporary works. 

The exhibition will begin with a launch event (see rewards) at which guests will have the opportunity to purchase the works of art, before an online auction is later opened, to audiences worldwide.  

 

The Background

Amid the horrors of Syria's civil war, hundreds of thousands of citizens have been killed and millions more displaced. This ancient nation of learning and art, of discovery and philosophy has been ravaged by warring factions while the world looks on. 

We have seen from afar the buildings destroyed, the thousands of people on-foot, searching for safety - the rows and rows of white tents in camps, housing those who managed to escape.

What can remain, in such a place? What can carry on, amid such chaos? What is left, after such loss?

Van Gogh once said - "Art is to console those who are broken by life". The motivation for this collaboration is to showcase inspiring artwork, and also to celebrate the impact art can have (on both artists and audiences) in times of war, and of turmoil. 

Khaled Youssef founded "Syria.Art" to serve the Syrian artistic community - while living in France and working as a surgeon, he devotes himself to seeking out new platforms to promote Syrian artists, curating exhibitions and building networks of support.

"During troubled times", says Khaled, it is "essential to offer another vision of Syria through its culture and the artistic creation of its artists."

Syria.Art has previously brought together collected visual works by established and emerging Syrian artists, hosted in both traditional galleries and on innovative online platforms. It has launched "Jasmin, une autre Syrie" - a web-based collection of art, poetry and other forms of literature, published quarterly in both French and English to explore the history, and cultural heritage of Syria.

Featured Artists

We are extremely proud to have secured contributions from the following artists, some living in Syria, some in Europe and other countries around the world:
 

Anas Farah

Nizar Ali Badr

Amr Fahd

Karam Alshamali 

Ayham Jabr

Julie Nakazi

Khaled Youssef

Omar Shammah

Obaida Zorik 

Tania Alkayyali

Humam Alsalim

Maisam mallisho

Samer Tarabichi 

Tarek Tuma 

Ammar Khaddour 

Dani Hasrouni

The artists will present in a broad range of media, and the works will give a rich, diverse depiction of Syria, both in peacetime and in conflict, and of everyday life and universal themes, 

 

What We Need

We are aiming to raise £8000 which will cover the cost of

- shipping original artwork/installations into the UK

- reproducing prints of other artwork submitted electronically

- displaying / framing/ hanging all artwork

- hosting events and talks as part of the exhibition

- publicising the event and the artists

- hosting the online auction and sending-out artworks to the highest bidders

- covering organisational costs

- any funds remaining at the end of the project will be donated directly tp Syria.Art

 

The Rewards

We have some great rewards lined-up in honour of the pledges we hope to receive, covering a range of small to large pledges. We are keeping the costs of these rewards low and their environmental impact in terms of air miles etc at a minimum. We hope you will find something that helps you to connect with this project and to keep as a lasting token of thanks for your support.

 

If you are unable to pledge financially, and/or if you are not near enough to Bangor to be able to attend the exhibition, here are some key ways to get involved and how your support:

- Share this crowdfunding campaign with your online networks

- Share the event page when it goes live on Facebook 

- Follow the online accounts of the featured artists and support their work

- Go to www.en.syriaartasso.com for details of previous and ongoing projects. and to see how you can show ongoing support, share information about their work, and enjoy the current projects for yourself

- Ask the artistic community in your area if they would consider hosting a similar exhibition in collaboration with Syria.Art

 

The Impact

Our hope is that once gathered and brought to public attention, this collection of powerful work will be invited to other towns and cities in Europe.

The auctions will be an opportunity to artists to fund their work and their development into the future. 

The exposure for the featured artists will provide them with future avenues for support and recognition

 

Risks & Challenges

There is a chance that we may raise less funding than we hope to, in which case the exhibition may have to be reduced in size and scope. 

We very much want the exhibition to be free for the public to view, but we may have to request a small entry fee to make the project possible, if we are unable to raise the funding we need.

story:
WELCOME TO THE DRAGONFLY FESTIVAL CAMPAIGN! 

WWW.DRAGONFLYFESTIVAL.ORG

“We are reaching out to all our friends & followers (& new friends we havent met yet!) to help us make this the best event it can be. For those of you who know us & understand what Dragonfly is then you know how important this is. For our new friends please get involved & get in touch & be part of this truly special event!  Help us become the first ever crowd funded multi-arts festival in Sweden: get involved, make it happen & help us to Keep the Dream Alive!” – Dragonfly Team 2013

Since 2008 up to 1000 visitors from all over the world contribute to a paradise of music, art, film & food.  At the core of the Dragonfly Festival lives a positive message to its audience & artists alike - appreciate the arts, be mindful of your surroundings & look after one another.

In the beginning we were just 5 friends from England on an adventure; looking for a way to share our love of music, art, innovation & the great outdoors. Now celebrating its 5th year, DF has evolved into so much more than that, more than we ever dared to dream. It is now a community-led festival, with a dedicated team of skilled volunteers with a passion to create a cultural arts platform nestled within Sweden’s breath taking landscape.

Dragonfly Festival exists to promote the value of creative practice & celebrate diverse musical & artistic styles. It is truly a unique event – a breath of fresh air in the festival climate. 

 

WE ARE YOURS!

Dragonfly still exists only because of the help, support & enthusiasm of so many people, who every year give their time, love & passion to create something extraordinarily special.

To keep this positive momentum going we need you, our friends and supporters, to put a little money in and help this unique event live on. We invite you to get in touch, get involved, get donating & help us produce the best Dragonfly Festival ever!

WE NEED YOU!

IT TAKES JUST 200 PEOPLE DONATING £50 TO ENSURE WE REACH OUR GOAL!

Over the years we have truly learned what Dragonfly Festival is all about: like every aspect of the festival it would not be possible without you - our audience & our community. 

By donating you will be ensuring the festivals future. We need to establish sustainability for the years to come. We have worked hard to gain funding from many sources every year but we need to move toward complete sustainability.

We need your support, we need your left over change, we need your pocket money, we need some of your beer money, what ever you can spare will go a LONG way.

 

THE GOODIES....

We have exclusive thank you gifts designed specifically for our audience, with rare & exclusive giveaways. Some of our lovely Dragonfly artist friends have generously offered a selection of amazing gifts to say thank you for your kind donation.

If you are coming to the festival then all your goodies will be waiting for you there. We can post your gifts if you are not able to come to the festival. We will do this once the campaign is complete.

LIMITED EDITION PRINTS

YUKIMI NAGANO:

Known for her success with the band Little Dragon, Yukimi has many creative talents! We are excited to present you with an exclusive Yukimi Nagano art print – available here only!

DANO WILHELMSSON:

Dragonfly’s resident artist & truly gifted painter/sculptor. Dano has been there since the start & has really helped form the identity of Dragonfly with his unique style of penmanship. GET THE ORIGINAL DRAGONFLY PRINT HERE ONLY!

KURT LIGHTNER:

A patriot of art & super talented graphic artist, Kurt is making an exclusive Dragonfly print especially for our campaign!

EXCLUSIVE LIVE DRAGONFLY ALBUMS!

Recorded live from the main-stage! We have been keeping these fantastic recordings all to ourselves but now it’s time to share this selection of Dragonfly highlights!

Each Album has 10 exclusive tracks recorded live from the Dragonfly Main-stage, you can’t hear this anywhere else!

DRAGONFLY T-SHIRT

This is an exclusive donators shirt, it's more than just clothing! Wear it with pride knowing that it means something truly special!

EXCLUSIVE 5-YEAR BRASS PATRON’S WRISTBANDS

Your contribution is BIG & we want to show you the reward you deserve! That’s why you get an exclusive solid brass, engraved wristband designed by founding member & jewellery artist Kathryn Gibson. Stylish & functional, this wristband ensures your entrance for the next 5 years!

WHAT HAPPENS IF WE DON’T MAKE IT?

We don’t want this year to be the last, so let’s reach & exceed the goal to ensure that we can keep creating festivals for decades to come, without being reliant on outside funding. Remember, the DF team works voluntarily, so all money raised goes straight into the cost of the Festival.  If we don’t make the funding goal then the festivals future will remain uncertain & won’t be able to achieve everything we have planned for the event this year. However we shall KEEP THE DREAM ALIVE!

DOES MY DONATION REALLY MAKE A DIFFERNCE?

It goes without saying, that Dragonlfy Festival wouldn’t be what it is without you. Without our friends, without our families, our supporters, our participants, without local businesses & without international collaboration, Df wouldn't exist. Now its time to build on this amazing support & ask you to contribute a little, & together we can achieve a lot.

WHAT IS MY MONEY GOING TO BE USED FOR?

Your donation will go towards the total cost of the festival, including artists fees, equipment, production costs, toilets,,,,,you name it! Please remember – none of us worker bees get paid, so your cash will go straight into the pot to cover the overall costs of the unique weekend event.

WHAT IF I CAN’T AFFORD TO DONATE?

  • Tell everyone you know to club together & donate whatever they can!
  • Ask folks to get the word out & make some noise about our campaign.
  • Post our plea to Facebook, Twitter, Instagram & anywhere else you can think of!
  • Ask a local business or work partner to sponsor us or donate.
  • Actions speak louder than words & we really need your help to actively spread the word of the festival so the community can thrive. 
  • Contribute to the programme, do what you're good at! Storytelling, juggling, yoga, massage, music, dancing or anything else; we are open to your ideas!
  • You can always volunteer & join our festival family if you can’t afford a ticket or want to be more involved.

WHY SUPPORT DRAGONFLY?

  • Dragonfly exists to promote the value of creative practice, & celebrate diverse musical & artistic styles.
  • The festival doesn’t aim to make a profit, or bring you music & art that’s popular on TV or in the charts – this is real people sharing real ideas & skills.
  • We all work for free – for the love of creating something vital, creative & engaging.
  • Ticket costs are cheap – we want to ensure everyone can afford to be involved.
  • Innovative music, skills sharing, inspiring art & good healthy food is at the top of our agenda.
  • We encourage participation – join our team, help us grow & improve!
  • With a strong international following, the festival aims to raise awareness & participation in creative practice, as well as provide a lasting network of influential techniques & collaboration. 
  • The festival site is beautiful. Set in a pre-historic recreation village, Ekehagen’s is a sight to behold.
  • The majority of our audience come back every year, some people have even moved out here! Until you see it, you wouldn’t believe this place!
  • Its just a great excuse for a damn good time & the freedom to be positive without boundaries!

Your contribution could make ALL the difference. As much as we have our fingers & toes crossed every year that we can pull this off & regardless of the AMAZING work done by so many people to keep the festival alive, the final CRUNCH is here. Without our audience, without you, without money, it just can’t keep happening!

USE THE INDIEGOGO SHARING LINKS TO HELP SPREAD THE LOVE!

Help us become the first ever crowd funded multi-arts festival in Sweden! Get involved, make it happen & ensure we all.... 

KEEP THE DREAM ALIVE! 

FOR MORE INFO VISIT WWW.DRAGONFLYFESTIVAL.ORG

DF TEAM xxxx
story_txt:
WELCOME TO THE DRAGONFLY FESTIVAL CAMPAIGN! 
WWW.DRAGONFLYFESTIVAL.ORG
“We are reaching out to all our friends & followers (& new friends we havent met yet!) to help us make this the best event it can be. For those of you who know us & understand what Dragonfly is then you know how important this is. For our new friends please get involved & get in touch & be part of this truly special event!  Help us become the first ever crowd funded multi-arts festival in Sweden: get involved, make it happen & help us to Keep the Dream Alive!” – Dragonfly Team 2013
Since 2008 up to 1000 visitors from all over the world contribute to a paradise of music, art, film & food.  At the core of the Dragonfly Festival lives a positive message to its audience & artists alike - appreciate the arts, be mindful of your surroundings & look after one another.
In the beginning we were just 5 friends from England on an adventure; looking for a way to share our love of music, art, innovation & the great outdoors. Now celebrating its 5th year, DF has evolved into so much more than that, more than we ever dared to dream. It is now a community-led festival, with a dedicated team of skilled volunteers with a passion to create a cultural arts platform nestled within Sweden’s breath taking landscape.
Dragonfly Festival exists to promote the value of creative practice & celebrate diverse musical & artistic styles. It is truly a unique event – a breath of fresh air in the festival climate. 
 
WE ARE YOURS!
Dragonfly still exists only because of the help, support & enthusiasm of so many people, who every year give their time, love & passion to create something extraordinarily special.
To keep this positive momentum going we need you, our friends and supporters, to put a little money in and help this unique event live on. We invite you to get in touch, get involved, get donating & help us produce the best Dragonfly Festival ever!

WE NEED YOU!
IT TAKES JUST 200 PEOPLE DONATING £50 TO ENSURE WE REACH OUR GOAL!
Over the years we have truly learned what Dragonfly Festival is all about: like every aspect of the festival it would not be possible without you - our audience & our community. 
By donating you will be ensuring the festivals future. We need to establish sustainability for the years to come. We have worked hard to gain funding from many sources every year but we need to move toward complete sustainability.
We need your support, we need your left over change, we need your pocket money, we need some of your beer money, what ever you can spare will go a LONG way.
 
THE GOODIES....
We have exclusive thank you gifts designed specifically for our audience, with rare & exclusive giveaways. Some of our lovely Dragonfly artist friends have generously offered a selection of amazing gifts to say thank you for your kind donation.
If you are coming to the festival then all your goodies will be waiting for you there. We can post your gifts if you are not able to come to the festival. We will do this once the campaign is complete.
