Идея разделить поэзию нашего семейного театра с людьми из большого города была очень сильной и это дало им силы поверить в большое путешествие через море. Они трудились целый год по привлечению средств, чтобы покрыть все расходы, кроме проезда. Мы были готовы помочь им столько, сколько могли, и согласились покрыть автомобильные перевозки из Швейцарии в Travenmünden паромного порта и обратно и от паромного порта Хельсинки в Санкт-Петербург . Средства на паром мы нашли у швейцарского фонда и подтвердили заказ. Огромные затраты за переправу должны были заплатить Швейцарский фонд и государственное финансирование, но в самую последнюю минуту, на прошлой неделе, оба дали нам отрицательный ответ. Поэтому нам сейчас необходимо  найти деньги на паром из Travenmünde до Хельсинки. Которых у нас нет… Удивительная паромная компания Финнлайнс пошла нам навстречу и проспонсировала половину стоимости билета. Наше глубокое и сердечное им спасибо. Вторую половину мы не знаем как  найти, но мы уверены, что сможем это сделать с вашей помощью! Осталось собрать 5200€ Мы увлечены силой повествования, театром и поиском ребенка в каждом из нас. Мы посвятили себя достижению высшего уровня мастерства, какое только возможно достичь. А также посещением городов и деревень. Мы стремимся охватить аудиторию в сельских местах, где нет регулярного доступа в театр. В результате мы живем в наших деревянных вагончиках круглый год, и наше турне длиться восемь месяцев каждый год и мы стараемся ехать туда, куда нас приглашают. Мы работаем с людьми и организациями, которые разделяют наши ценности и нашу страстную веру в театр, в истории, и в нашего зрителя.Спасибо, если вы сможете помочь нам, в любом случае, пусть это будет совсем немного.х Н&мDEUTSCH: Liebe Freunde
Wir durch ein Wunder sind wir nun doch
alle zusammen auf der grossen Fähre nach Helsinki… Oben auf dem Deck scheint
die Sonne unten im Bach der Schiffes sind unsere Wohnwagen, LKWs, Theaterzelt, Buffet, Bühne, Kostüme… Wir, Nicole und Martin
und die ganze Crew mit Hund Kind und Kegel geniessen einen Moment der Ruhe.
Wir werden von Helsinki weiter reisen
nach Russland  dort um dort in St.
Petersburg an einem Festival 3 Wochen lang zu spielen (25. April-15. Mai 2015).
Die Gesuche um finanzielle Unterstützung
wurden leider abgelehnt. So sind  nun
Robert und Albert noch unterwegs um auf Ihre Weise zu helfen… Das Mädchen ohne
Hände ist zuversichtlich und schaut in die Ferne übers Meer…
Realität ist dass die Hänfahrt nun
bezahlt wurde dank einem 50% Rabatt der Finnline Fähren. 
Die
Kosten der Rückreise 5’200€ müssen wir aber nun in kurzer Zeit auftreiben. 
Wir sind ein
unabhängiges Theater-Ensemble, gegründet von den beiden Schauspielern Nicole
Gubler Schranz und Martin Gubler  und
produzieren, kreieren und spielen unsere eigenen Stücke. Wir folgten dem Wunsch
eine neue Art Volkstheater ins Leben zu rufen: Theater als Erlebnis- und
Begegnungsort für  alle Menschen
unabhängig von Alter, sozialer Herkunft, und Lebenssituation. 
Wir spielen auf Einladung von Veranstaltern und Festivals, aber
auch für Schulen und soziale Einrichtungen. Nicht immer handelt es sich dabei um
professionelle Organisationen, sondern auch um Menschen welche getragen sind
von gleichen Ideen und  Werten und die
Arbeit auf freiwilliger Basis leisten.
Die Menschen
von Teater
Circus Mongolfieri aus St. Petersburg haben
uns vor zwei Jahren in der Schweiz gesehn. Begeistert von unserer Arbeit und
unserem Projekt planen sie nun seit Monaten dieses Festival und freuen uns auf
den kulturellen und freundschftlichen Austausch und auf die Aufführungen von
uns in der grossen Stadt. Viele Hebel wurden von den guten Menschen in Bewegung
gesetzt um dies zu realisieren. Die Kosten vor Ort und die Aufführungen sind gedeckt.
Dir grossen Kosten der Überschiffung des ganzen Fahrzeuge und dem Zelt
übersteigen aber bei Weitem die Möglichkeiten der kleinen sozialen Theater
Gemeinschaft. 
Begeistert vom
Theaterspielen, von der Kraft des Geschichten Erzählens und von der Umsetzung
symbolischer Uhrthemen in gesprochener, musikalischer, artistischer und
getanzter Weise sind wir getragen von der Faszination und dem Glauben an ein
Theater bei welchem sich alle Bühnenkünste als Ausdrucksmittel vereinen. So
glauben auch wir an dieses Projekt in Russland.
Daher der Aufruf an Euch alle, liebe Freunde. Wir freuen uns auf
jede Spende, ob gross oder klein! Ihr helft uns damit nach Russland und wieder
zurück zu fahren! Ahoi!
ENGLISH: Hello, Martin and Nicole here, wondering, for the first time like this, if any angels out there are able to help us…? We to sailed to Russia on Tuesday, with our theatre tent, costumes, characters and crew. We had just heard that the Swiss
funding for our trip to Russia (25th April until 12th May 2015) had not come through, but we took the risk to come. So Albert and Robert are scratching
their heads and the rooster is ringing the bell very loudly. Only The Girl is
calm and knows all will be well…..
We need to raise 5200€ for the boat.We are an independent not-for-profit
traveling theatre company that creates, produces, performs and tours our own
work. We were founded out of a desire to create truly communal theatre without
borders of location, age, language, money or background. We travel with our own theatre
tent which we put up everywhere that we go.
A year ago Teater Circus Mongolfieri, a not-for-profit
organisation from St. Petersburg fell in love with our work and invited us to
bring our performances to their brand new festival, in Russia. The idea to
share our poetic community theatre with the people from this big city was
strong and gives them the power to believe in this big journey across the sea. They
worked hard all year and raised funds to cover all the costs, apart from the travel. We were ready to
help them as much as we could, and agreed to cover the road
transports costs ourselves, for the drive from Switzerland to Travenmünden ferry port and
back and from Helsinki ferry port to St. Petersburg by road. Both ways. For the
ferry itself we applied for Swiss funding, and confirmed
the booking. 
The huge cost of shipment should have been paid by a
Swiss foundation and government funding, but at the very last minute, last
week, both gave us a negative reply. So it is up to us now to find also money
for the ferry from Travenmünde to Helsinki. We do not have it. The amazing
ferry company Finnlines stepped  and sponsored half the ticket
price. Our deep and heartfelt thanks to them. For the other half, we don’t know
how to do it, but we are sure that we can make it happen with your help! 
We still need to raise 5200€ We are passionate about the power of storytelling,
about theatre, and about reaching the child in all of us. We have dedicated
ourselves to reaching the highest level of skill we possibly can. As well as
visiting towns, cities and villages, we are committed to reaching audiences in
rural locations where there is not regular access to theatre. As a result we
live in our wooden wagons all the year round, and tour for eight months each
year, and try to go anywhere we are invited. We work with people and
organisations who share our values and our passionate belief in theatre, in
stories, and in our audiences.Thank you if you are able to help us, in anyway however seemingly small.x n&mFRANCAIS:  Hello, c’est nous, Nicole et Martin,
pour la première fois demander ainsi,  et
pourquoi pas,  n’y aurait’il pas quelques
anges sur terre prêts à nous aider….? Grâce à la Compagnie de bateau Finnlines
et son soutient (elle offre la moité des frais du bateau) on a pu prendre le
bateau mardi, avec notre théâtre, nos costumes, nos personnages et notre
équipe. Par contre on a malheureusement appris que notre demande de soutient
financier Suisse pour la deuxième moité des frais de voyages en Russie (25 avril
au 12 mai) n’est pas passée. Ainsi Albert et Robert s’arrachent les cheveux
quand au coq, lui il crie à toute voix sur tous les toits de la ville. Seule la
jeune fille sans mains est calme et sait que tout ira bien…
Bon…nous devons atteindre encore  la somme de 5200 euros.
Nous sommes une compagnie indépendante à
but non lucratif qui crée, joue et tourne avec son propre théâtre. Un profond
désir de créer un propre théâtre populaire sans barrières d’âge, de langue,
d’argent, de lieu nous a animé dès le début du projet. Nous voyageons avec
notre propre théâtre-chapiteau que nous implantons là où nous allons. 
Il y a une année le Teater Circus
Mongolfieri, une organisation à but non lucratif également, de St. Petersburg à
eu un coup de foudre pour notre travail et nous invite à venir jouer à leur
nouveau festival en Russie. L’idée de partager nos spectacles, notre univers
poétique chez eux fut si forte qu’elle leur donna toute la force de croire en
la réalisation de ce projet et de cette traversée en bateau. Ils ont travaillé
sans relâche durant une année pour nous donner la possiblité de réaliser leur
rêve. Ils ont fait  recours à des
demandes de subventions pour couvrir les frais, sauf ceux du voyage. Nous
sommes prêts à les aider et à prendre en charge les frais de voyage de la
Suisse au port de Travenmünden (aller et retour) et pour la partie sur les
routes du port de Helsinki à St. Petersburg. Pour le bateau nous avons fait des
demandes au fondations Suisse et confirmer la réservation du bateau. 
Au dernier moment, elles ont répondu
négativement. C’est pourquoi c’est à nous maintenant de trouver l’argent pour
les frais du bateau de Helsinki a Travenmünden. Cet argent, nous ne l’avons
pas!
Avec votre aide, nous pouvons, nous
espérons par ce biais rassembler l’argent pour le coût d’une traversée. 
Nous devons encore atteindre la somme de
5200 Euros. 
Nous sommes
passionnés par les contes, le théâtre et la beauté de pouvoir apporter ces
spectacles à l’enfant qui est en nous tous. Nous donnons tout pour réaliser nos
visions profondes, pour aller jouer dans les grandes villes comme dans les
petits villages où il n’y a que très peu de culture. C’est pourquoi nous vivons
dans des roulottes en bois durant toute l’année et tournons huit mois dans
l’année. Nous essayons de nous rendre partout où les gens nous invitent. Nous
collaborons avec des personnes et des associations qui partagent nos valeurs et
notre passion, qui croient au théâtre, aux contes et au public. 
Merci si vous pouvez nous aider, aussi
par un petit soutient, à aller jouer en Russie!
ITALIANO: Ciao, siamo Martin e Nicole, ed è la prima volta che chiediamo un aiuto in questo modo, chissà se ci sono degli angeli in grado di aiutarci? Abbiamo navigato per raggiungere la Russia martedì, con la nostra tenda teatro, costumi, personaggi e l'equipaggio. Avevamo appena saputo che il finanziamento svizzero per il nostro viaggio in Russia (dal 25 aprile al 12 maggio 2015), non era arrivato, ma abbiamo voluto lo stesso rischiare e siamo partiti. Così Albert e Robert si grattano la testa e il gallo lancia l'allarme a voce molto alta. Solo la fanciulla è calma e sa che tutto andrà bene… Noi abbiamo bisogno di raccogliere 5200 € per il battello. Siamo una Compagnia indipendente che viaggia, non-profit, che crea, produce, recita e porta in tour il proprio teatro. Siamo nati con il desiderio di creare un teatro veramente comune, senza frontiere, età, lingua, denaro di sfondo. Viaggiamo con la nostra tenda teatro che abbiamo portato un po 'ovunque. Un anno fa il Circo Teater Mongolfieri, un teatro no profit di San Pietroburgo, si è innamorato del nostro lavoro e ci ha invitato a portare le nostre creazioni al loro nuovo festival, in Russia. L'idea di condividere il nostro poetico teatro con la gente di questa grande città era forte e ha dato loro la forza di credere in questo grande viaggio attraverso il mare. Hanno lavorato duramente tutto l'anno e raccolto fondi per coprire tutti i costi, a parte il viaggio. Eravamo pronti ad aiutarli, e abbiamo accettato di coprire i costi del trasporto dalla Svizzera al porto di Travenmünden e, tornando indietro, dal porto di Helsinki a San Pietroburgo su strada. Andata e ritorno. Per il traghetto abbiamo fatto domanda per il finanziamento svizzero, e confermato la prenotazione. L'enorme costo del viaggio sarebbe dovuto essere pagato dal finanziamento di una fondazione e dal governo svizzero, ma all'ultimo minuto, la scorsa settimana, entrambi ci hanno dato una risposta negativa. Quindi sta a noi ora trovare anche i soldi per il traghetto da Travenmünde a Helsinki. Noi non li abbiamo! La compagnia di traghetti Finnlines, ha fatto un passo straordinario, è intervenuta e ha sponsorizzato la metà del prezzo del biglietto. A loro va il nostro profondo grazie di cuore. Per l'altra metà, non sappiamo come fare, ma siamo sicuri che possiamo far accadere questo miracolo con il vostro aiuto! Abbiamo ancora bisogno di raccogliere 5200 €. Amiamo enormemente il potere della narrazione, il teatro, e raggiungere il bambino che vive in ognuno di noi. Ci siamo dedicati con passione a raggiungere il più alto livello di abilità possibile. Oltre a visitare le città, e i villaggi, ci siamo impegnati a raggiungere il pubblico in zone rurali dove è molto difficile accedere regolarmente al teatro. Viviamo nei nostri carri di legno tutto l'anno, e in tour per otto mesi l'anno, e cerchiamo di andare ovunque siamo invitati. Noi lavoriamo con le persone e le organizzazioni che condividono i nostri valori e la nostra fede appassionata nel teatro, nelle storie, e nel nostro pubblico. Grazie se riuscirete ad aiutarci, anche con poco.x n&m

story:
This is my first professional project since graduating from The Sir John Cass School of Art, Architecture and Design (London Metropolitan University) earlier this year. Although I am a relative unknown, I hope to bring these original products to market through the advantageous and accessible model of crowdfunding. These products are:

Cardboard Ceramics

Corrugated cups formed from cardboard coffee cups sleeves. The moulds are filled with clay, and then burnt away in the kiln. Since the moulds are disposable, they can create dense, overlapping textures, whilst leaving the ceramics inside intact. The stoneware cups bear the rough gesture of the cardboard, as if they are made of petrified paper.

This is: the Lost Cardboard Technique. A reaction to our hugely wasteful culture of disposable coffee products. Hundreds of thousands of paper cups and sleeves are used every day - only ever for about two minutes - before being thrown away. They are rarely ever recycled.

Cardboard Ceramics turns these generic pieces of disposable cardboard into distinctive pieces of ceramic tableware. They are tactile, handmade, and rich with individual character - the antithesis of the mundane, expendable sleeves they are made from.

Why do I need funding?

I created the Lost Cardboard Technique while studying at The Cass, in London. Since graduating earlier this year, I have been eager to continue the Cardboard Ceramics project, but no longer have the equipment to do so. Your kind pledges will help me buy a kiln, an extraction unit (the burning cardboard gives off a lot of smoke!), and the materials needed to make the first batch of these cups. 

You will be helping me make works of intriguing, original design, and opposing the unsustainable culture of waste in which we live. This kiln will be the foundation of my own design studio, and will be the start of many more creative endeavours to come.

The future of Cardboard Ceramics

When I was developing the Lost Cardboard Technique, I created a whole population of weird and wonderful experimental vessels. They helped me understand what could be achieved with clay-filled cardboard. Many of these experiments could be further developed into fully realised designs - bringing new additions to the Cardboard Ceramics range. Having a kiln of my own will be essential for this, and will help me continue my creative pursuits into exciting new territories..

Thanks very much for your support!

story:
Hello! I'm Jo and I am a Scenic Artist, currently studying at RCS in Glasgow. I have a work placement in literally one of the most amazing Scenic studios early next year in upstate New York. I am sooo excited to be going and literally can't wait to get out there and be painting in my favourite place. It's my dream to be a Scenic Artist, and a dream to get a placement out in New York, and I am working my butt off to make sure that happens!

I have been doing Illustration commissions for you guys for a while now (sincerest thanks to anyone who has ever bought one of my pieces!). My idea is this: I will open up my commission books and paint as many illustrations as I can before I go. If you have ever wanted an illustration from me and were not sure of what to ask for, or who to get one for, or anything - now is the time! Christmas is coming up, an illustration would be ideal as a personalised gift and you can have literally anything you want - you know I love my pop culture references - the crazier and more obscure the better! Or if you want to have a family moment captured, or a cute pet portrait - anything goes and I am happy to oblige.

 

I am trying to raise £500 to help go towards my expenses for this trip. This will help go towards my Air bnb, my food, my flight home etc. And I want to use the skills I have to be able to help pay for this. 

Illustration Commissions will cost £35.00, and as I mentioned before, they can be of any subject of your choosing. The illustrations will be A4 in size and on watercolour paper, and will come delivered to you packaged in an A4 postage box ( Postage applies and UK delivery only - for worldwide commissions please just message!) :) 

I am running this campaign all the way up until I leave for New York so I will have plenty time to paint as many as I can, however if you would like something specifically as a gift for Christmas, please just let me know so I can accommodate my time. These will be delivered to you via Royal Mail in an A4 postage box (UK only). I will send these out to you throughout December/January as soon as they are ready however if you have a specific date in mind (Christmas/birthday etc) let me know and I will accommodate!

I am just trying to earn some extra money to help go towards this, please understand that I am also working my butt off with several other jobs to help make this happen too! I sincerely appreciate any help so even if you don't want a commission, a wee share of my goal on your social media is also so much appreciated :) 

Thank You

Jo

story:
The intention of this body installation is to use the Kudzu vine as a metaphor for fear.  The installation consists of an individual ensnared in a large-scale structure and subsequent body adornments that surround and cover the subject in my version of Kudzu until they are unrecognizable or barely detectible to the viewer.  The work is meant to be both about the installation itself as a powerful visual interpretation of fear, but also an emotional experiment to gage the reactions of both the kudzu covered individual and the audience.   The construction and vines are made of steel and copper components. The leaves are cast Kudzu paper, imprinted with various definitions of fear gathered from surveys.

The Installation will be exhibited in the OGLETHORPE GALLERY in Savannah, GA May 10-12 2012. There will be three nights of exhibition and a different performing art student will be trapped in my Kudzu adornment each night. I have also hired a sound design student to create an original score that consists of a creepy melody with sound bytes from the creative process (i.e. paper blender, torch fire, steel forging, etc) then at the end of the 15 minute song there will be an interlude of overlapping voices talking about Fear. During the music the performing art student is meant to be frozen and almost unseen, then when the voices being the actress will come alive and desperately ask the audience for help.

I have spent over 300 hours making my hand made leaves out of leaves from the actual Kudzu plant that I harvested and then ground up into a paper pulp. The pulp is then pressed in to copper plates that have words etched on them to emboss the paper. Then I use towels to roll out the moisture. Once the pulp is pressed and dried I hand cut the paper into leaf forms and burn them with a torch to make the words stand out. At the moment I have roughly 3316 leaves!

The body adornment pieces are all sculpted by hand out of various gauges of copper wire. Once sculpted the pieces are sand blasted and treated with a chemical patina to make the copper turn a ghostly green shade. 

The base of the structure is a chair that a sculpture student helped me weld out of steel and painted to mimic the copper green patina. the seat of the chair I have woven out of Kudzu vines. 

This body installation is the grandest project I have ever attempted, it is the embodiment of who I am as an artist and as a human being. I consider it an ideal marriage of metal work, sculpture, concept, and performance art. Your support with help me cover the costs of copper wire, my exhibition space, compensation for the student artists that have assisted me, and the various other elements that will bring this installation to life! THANK YOU!

The base of the structure is a chair that a sculpture student helped me weld out of steel and painted to mimic the copper green patina. the seat of the chair I have woven out of Kudzu vines. 
This body installation is the grandest project I have ever attempted, it is the embodiment of who I am as an artist and as a human being. I consider it an ideal marriage of metal work, sculpture, concept, and performance art. Your support with help me cover the costs of copper wire, my exhibition space, compensation for the student artists that have assisted me, and the various other elements that will bring this installation to life! THANK YOU!

story:
Help me build a bridge!

My name is Nita Sturiale and my past and present is intertwined with Sicily.

I have been a Professor at the Massachusetts College of Art and Design in Boston for more than 15 years, am currently the department chair, and have been the project manager for many successful endeavors in the arts and in business.

I have been traveling to Sicily every summer for 14 years with my Sicilian husband and children. I have reconnected with my own Sicilian heritage, visited the towns of my grandparents, and been embraced by my husband’s family and friends. I’ve made my own personal artwork during these summer months, but for years, I have wanted to share the sights, sounds, tastes, and incredible Sicilian generosity with my students and artist friends. “Regali Artist Residency in Sicily” is the culmination of that desire.

Over the course of 2 weeks in July, 5 American artists and 5 Italian artists will collaborate and interview several families in the rural Sicilian town of Favara. These families will tell us their stories about a special gift in their lives. These stories and gifts will be collected and displayed in a multi-media exhibition at a gallery in Favara. We will also design a catalog of the project. 

We invite you to become a part of Regali and share the joy of gifting, story telling, and all things Sicilian!

“Our gifts, if we hold onto them, are worthless until they are shared.” Reverend Peter Boullata

Nita handing out gifts to Sicilian women
as part of her Pietre Preziose project of 2008

This project, Regali, is symbol of gratitude to my grandfather for his Sicilian heritage, as well as his bravery to seek a better life for himself and his children in America. It is an apology to my father-in-law for taking his son far away. It is a promise to my daughters that they will have the power to invent a future for themselves that is the best of both worlds.

Regali: Nita’s personal motivation

My grandfather was born in upstate New York in 1906. Around 1908, he was taken back to his mother’s homeland, Altofonte, Sicily, and stayed there until he was 18. Because his mother insisted that he keep his American citizenship, he received no Italian schooling other than what he learned on the dusty Sicilian streets. Around 1924, during the beginnings of Italian Fascist rule in Italy, he traveled back to upstate New York in the middle of winter without coat on his back. He escaped the direction of his country and the lack of opportunity for himself. He came to the US and rarely looked back to Sicily for sustenance or guidance – even discouraging his sons to speak the language. His story is not dissimilar to so many immigrants from so many countries – ambitious individuals escaping lack of opportunity or worse and aspiring for something better.

Fast-forward to year 2000, I marry a Sicilian, also in the US for ambitious reasons. However, instead of running away from Sicily, we make a decision to maintain our connection, dependency, and stewardship of our Sicilian family and olive yard. This translates into a month-long trip every summer with our children into the arms of our nonni, cugini, and amici in Agrigento. For 13 years I have written, photographed, and mulled over my relationship to Sicily, my children, and the complicated clash between tradition and contemporary reality.

As an artist and teacher, I have long been interested in the psychology and biology of community, learning, and labor. I have wanted to make visible the contributions of the lesser celebrated – the mothers, the house-keepers, the farmers, the peddlers, the students, the artists. Currently, Sicily is in economic shambles with 38.8 percent of young people without jobs, twice the national average. Corruption, despondency, and depression is high and locals feel invisible in the global theater. Our grandfathers’ flights continue to have relevancy. Yet, you have never had a peach unless you’ve tasted one from Sicily. The food, the family loyalty, the intense commitment to survival and beauty – I affirm that these assets are to be preserved in a climate of change, globalism, and capitalist bullying. 

During these many summers, I have prepared myself and my supporters in the small town of Favara, Sicily, to embark on a project, entitled "Regali", that will bring many of these interests together while also providing opportunities for several participants, both Italian and American, to bridge our cultural divide and celebrate the individual stories of the citizens of Favara. Over the course of 2 weeks, 5 American artists and 5 Italian artists will form teams and interview 30 families in the rural Sicilian town of Favara that have a story to tell about a special gift in their lives. These stories and gifts will be collected into an exhibition at a gallery in Favara.

We are collaborating with Farm Cultural Park, a new contemporary arts center in the midst of Favara, founded by Andrea Bartoli in 2010.

The Farm is an ambitious and exciting urban renewal project that has transformed the run-down and semi-abandoned heart of Favara into a modern art exhibition and community space. Artists, tourists and locals have come from far and wide and the Farm’s efforts have begun to revitalize Favara. The Farm has several gallery spaces, a bookshop, apartments, and an open mind. They have offered exhibition space, lodging for the visiting artists, as well as logistics and installation support. This collaboration would be the first of its kind with the United States. 


We have invited 4 young emerging American artists to participate in Regali. We will be sharing their stories periodically throughout the campaign. We are also working closely with Lisa Wade, an International artist living in Italy that will be managing logistics in Favara.  You can read more about the participating artists on our Regali blog.

"Regali" intertwines the fields of fine art, story telling, social practice, education, and community development. It will contribute to the resolve of the Sicilian people to survive in an extremely depressed area during severe recession and continuous corruption. The Farm Cultural Park has already begun to contribute to the livability of Sicily and its revitalization. New hotels and restaurants have emerged and the local medieval castle has been renovated in its wake. This project will further these efforts as well as share the gifts of the Sicilian people with those of us who are supposedly better off. My goal is to trigger conversations about defining the quality of life, the assets of an ancient culture, and how we determine the “best practices” of old and new.

What We Need

  • We need to buy 5 American artists round-trip airfare from the US to Sicily from July 14 - July 27.  
  • All the artists will to need to eat while we are working!
  • As many locals in Favara speak Italian and Sicilian, we need translation services. 
  • We need to offset the costs of our Italian collaborator, Lisa Wade, who will be doing the lion-share of the Sicilian preparatory work before we arrive. 
  • We will need to pay for printing materials for the photo documentation to be included in gallery exhibition. 

Ideal Project Budget:

Airfare for American artists   $5,000 $1000 towards ticket price x 5 artists
Per diem for all artists   $4,200 10 artists x $30 a day x 14 days
Framing/exhibiton/printing supplies   $2,000
Translation services   $2,600 2 translators x 10 days x $160/day
Logistics management in Sicily   $2,000 for prep before we arrive and during the residency organizing italian artists and gallery. 
Total -  $15,800 

What We Have

  • A commitment from Farm Cultural Park to house the 5 American artists in Favara during the period July 14 - July 27 for FREE!
  • A commitment from Lisa Wade to secure the Favara citizens willing to be interviewed for this project.
  • 5 talented artists ready to buy a plane ticket.  
  • A network of family and friends in Sicily that will help with logistics, transportation, and translation. 
  • A strong connection to an institution here in the US, Massachusetts College of Art, that can host an reciprocal exhibition in the future and in is the process of developing an international course based on this project. 
  • A strong connection to the Italian Consulate in Boston.

What You Get

Aside from that warm feeling of being involved and engaged in an international conversation, you will receive one of the following based on your level of support:

  • A photo journal on the Regali blog that will be updated regularly with images of the artists, families and activities as we prepare to leave and while we are in Sicily.
  • Inside access to behind the scenes video.
  • A chance to take part in a LIVE Skype greeting with Favarians.
  • A limited edition print of the Regali project poster an original postcard art series designed by participating artists. 
  • The chance to exhibit your submissions to our Gift Art Wall in Sicily. 
  • Sicilian organic olive oil.
  • Producers credit to be displayed on the Gallery wall during the duration of the exhibition at the Farm Cultural Park in Favara Sicily during the Summer of 2014. 
  • For the Italian-Americans in our audience, you'll feel a vital link from America to Italy. 
The Sturiale-Vassallo-Taibi-Franklin-Dymek family in the US.


If we do not reach our ambitious goal, I plan to embark on this project in any configuration I can. We will adjust to using less participating artists, interviewing less families, and editing less video documentation.  The factors that will remain in place with any level of funding are: 

  • The time frame - July 14 - July 27.
  • Our invitation to stay in Favara as a guest of the Farm Cultural Park. 
  • The general conceptual structure - interviewing locals about a special object and reshaping the interviews into a gallery exhibition.  

This is the first year of the this project. I plan to return the following summer for part 2. 

A Bit More About What led to "Regali"

During our annual summer trip to Sicily, I am struck by the treasure-trove of objects in my father-in-law’s house that represent several lifetimes of acquisition. For him each painting, figurine, sterling silver money clip, or vintage car, is a story, a memory, a way of proving the relevancy of his nationality and connection to tradition. Though his generosity with us is extreme and unconditional, we live an ocean and a sea away and these objects inevitably stay with Nonno. Each time his son leaves “home” and returns to the US with his American wife, I feel we chip away at the importance of these objects. Sicilian culture is often sited for its hospitality and warmth. It is true. In Sicily, gift giving is an obsession, a cultural norm and highly refined system. The research of Paul Zak and others has shown that the act of giving has also been linked to the release of oxytocin, a hormone that induces feelings of warmth, euphoria, trust, and connection to others: more generosity, more empathy, stronger community. Giving changes us at a molecular level.

Why Support Us?

  Nita Sturiale, Project Director

I am defined by my passion as a mother and teacher. I have 2 young daughters (7 and 10) and I have been teaching in the Studio for Interrelated Media at the Massachusetts College of Art and Design for more than 10 years. These two identities flow in and out of each other and both inspire the artwork that I produce. The Studio for Interrelated Media is a unique and groundbreaking undergraduate program that allows for both a highly individualized and an interdisciplinary plan of study. Our students become experts at collaboration, live event production, and articulating their artistic visions. For the last three years, I have been the chair of this department. I teach courses exploring career skills, event planning and production, the intersection of art and science, and multi-media production. I have been a project manager for several large-scale collaborations. During the spring of 2013, my class, Art and Science Immersive Media, produced an original 45 minute full-dome audio/video show at the Boston Museum of Science’s Hayden Planetarium. In 2008, I began a multi-year project in which I gifted 12 Sicilian women gemstone necklaces representing a particular hormone. This project became a website followed by a book. In 2003, I led a team of 5 artists in the first flash-based, GPS-enabled artwalk through the Boston Common as part of the Boston Cyberarts Festival. I speak a fair amount of Italian and have already put in place several organizations and individuals in Sicily ready to begin this project.


 Lisa Wade, Italy Co-Director

Lisa Wade is an American-born artist living in Italy for many years. She is a conceptual artist working with socio-political content using video, installation, and painting. She has exhibited all over Europe and the United States. She is an experienced teacher and mentor. As an American woman in Sicily, Lisa shares many of the same perspectives as Nita does, however, having lived there for so long, she is far more embedded in the culture and more adept in the language. Lisa writes, “As an American living overseas, I am daily switching between English and Italian, American and European perspectives, literal and metaphorical meanings. I often complete sentences in whichever language offers the more descriptive finish. In my art, I use diverse materials as I do different languages. No one material is more significant than the others, I use them all together to express myself to the fullest.” Lisa will as act a mentor for the artistic teams, the artistic director of the gallery installation and my main communication link with the Farm staff. 


Our Supporters!


Giuseppe Pasorelli, Consoloto Generale d’Italia, Boston Massachusetts

"Regali, which means 'gifts' in Italian, is an appropriate name for Nita's project not only for the gifts of objects that the project will entail, but also for the gifts to Favara and to New England that this project represents. It is a gift to Favara and to Sicily as this creative undertaking will remind the people of Favara of their meaningful stories and how these very stories make their community so vibrant. It is a gift to New England because it celebrates the history and future between our two countries, and in particular, the friendship between Boston and Sicily from where so many of our Italian immigrants have originated."



Andrea Bartoli, Founding Director of Farm Cultural Park

"Nita’s project fits right into our efforts here. We have not yet welcomed a group of American artists to our community. Having the opportunity to share ideas, stories and meals with this group will not only enhance cross cultural relations but will invigorate our local community during very challenging times.  Finally, her work comes from a particularly powerful place – as a Sicilian American married to a Sicilian native, Nita has the drive to see this project through to a successful and meaningful finish."


Olio Taibi has donated your gifts of 100% organic single-estate extra virgin olive oil from Sicily.  Please visit the Olio Taibi website for THAT Sicilian story!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to support this project at this time - no worries! If you like the sound of this project please share this page with your family and friends.  We can do it with your help and support. There are many share tools on the Indiegogo site that you can use the spread the word!

Thank your for reading this far down the page!

story:
Short Summary

Create is a community organization creating opportunities for expression, enjoyment and appreciation of the arts and humanities through individual and community participation. Our vision is to create a dynamic community in which the energy of the arts promotes a quality of life rich in color, texture and depth. Create has classes and events for all ages, but childrens' education is the heart of Create.

At Create we encourage individual and community development in every form of the arts. From painting, drawing, sewing, dancing, photography, singing, acting, weaving, or any other "art," it can be found at Create. We support aspiring, novice, beginner, intermediate, advanced, or professional artists, and encourage every level to participate and develop the inner artist found in all of us.

What We Need & What You Get

Create has been in constant operation for over 20 years. Because we live in a depressed area, raising local money to fund our operation has become a challenge. We own our building and property, but operating costs and programs exceed our ability to keep it constantly funded.  It is our goal to provide a facility to encourage our adults and our youth to participate in the arts and learn to express themselves through art. 

  • For every $100 dollars donated, we will mail the donor a "fused glass" Christmas Ornament.
  • For every $200 dollars donated, we will send you five 2013 Capitol Christmas Tree Cards with a photo of the tree before it was cut. (It grew in our area.) In addition, we will send one Capitol Christmas Tree Commemorative Ornament.

If we don't reach our entire goal, any funds that are donated will help to keep Create alive and functioning.  Every little bit helps!

The Impact

An example of Create's impact on our local community is our recent moccasin class.  24 people attended the class, including a father with a developmentally delayed teenage son, a grandmother with two grandchildren, a mother with four teenage girls, a set of parents with  two teenage boys. Attendees learned how to create their own moccasins from leather.  The experience was so positive that the local elementary school asked us to repeat the class for 75 third graders.

Because the cost of leather would have been cost prohibitive, we used upholstery material.  One third grade boy had never seen a needle before this class, let alone having ever sewn anything. 

Because it was National American Indian History month, the Kalispel Tribe of  Indians put on an assembly for the children where the children listened to drumming and learned to dance and show off their moccasins.  The children learned about local history, along with learning a skill.

Other Ways You Can Help

We recognize that not everyone can donate.  But everyone can help pass the word.  Please let others know about our needs.  Talk to your firiends and relatives.  We will appreciate it.  And dont forget to use Indiegogo share tools.
story_txt:
Short SummaryCreate is a community organization creating opportunities for expression, enjoyment and appreciation of the arts and  humanities through individual and community  participation. Our vision is to create a dynamic community in which the energy of the  arts promotes a quality of life rich in color, texture and depth. Create has classes and events for all ages, but childrens' education is the heart of Create.At Create we encourage individual and community development in every form of the arts. From painting, drawing, sewing, dancing, photography, singing, acting, weaving, or any other "art," it can be found at Create. We support aspiring, novice, beginner, intermediate, advanced, or professional artists, and encourage every level to participate and develop the inner artist found in all of us.What We Need & What You GetCreate has been in constant operation for over 20 years. Because we live in a depressed area, raising local money to fund our operation has become a challenge. We own our building and property, but operating costs and programs exceed our ability to keep it constantly funded.  It is our goal to provide a facility to encourage our adults and our youth to participate in the arts and learn to express themselves through art.  
For every $100 dollars donated, we will mail the donor a "fused glass" Christmas Ornament.
For every $200 dollars donated, we will send you five 2013 Capitol Christmas Tree Cards with a photo of the tree before it was cut. (It grew in our area.) In addition, we will send one Capitol Christmas Tree Commemorative Ornament.
If we don't reach our entire goal, any funds that are donated will help to keep Create alive and functioning.  Every little bit helps!The ImpactAn example of Create's impact on our local community is our recent moccasin class.  24 people attended the class, including a father with a developmentally delayed teenage son, a grandmother with two grandchildren, a mother with four teenage girls, a set of parents with  two teenage boys. Attendees learned how to create their own moccasins from leather.  The experience was so positive that the local elementary school asked us to repeat the class for 75 third graders.Because the cost of leather would have been cost prohibitive, we used upholstery material.  One third grade boy had never seen a needle before this class, let alone having ever sewn anything.  Because it was National American Indian History month, the Kalispel Tribe of  Indians put on an assembly for the children where the children listened to drumming and learned to dance and show off their moccasins.  The children learned about local history, along with learning a skill. Other Ways You Can HelpWe recognize that not everyone can donate.  But everyone can help pass the word.  Please let others know about our needs.  Talk to your firiends and relatives.  We will appreciate it.  And dont forget to use Indiegogo share tools.

story:
Hello, My name is cory, I am a recent graduate from Rocky Mountain College of Art + Design, with a degree in Game Art. Just before graduating my computer died becoming unusuable, hindering my ability to use the skills learned to school, working on independant projects, and other things.

As such I am proposing this so I can get the money I need for  computer while I work on job hunting. My hero in life is Matt Groening the creator of The Simpsons. I would not be in art if it was not for his show and I wouldnt be the man I am today. So in respect for him I would like funding to do 100 pictures of Matt in 100 days.This will give me a chance to work on different projects while I am trying to find work in my field, and developing my skill further. 

Firstly the funding will go to getting me a new computer that can be used for my profession as well as some needed accessories, such as replacing the pen of a tablet used for digital painting. A small amount will be used to pay for basic internet services to post the images online on a blog I will put together for the project. Lastly the remainder will be used for traditional art supplies, such as paints, oil pastels, whatever is needed for each picture. Anything over the goal will go into the project if need be but will likely help with cost of living.

Now for some of the perks.

  • Anyone who helps fund will receive access to the blog so that they can see the pictures as they come out
  •  For the people who give $25 or more will be given invites to Live Stream events where they can watch the pictures being created and in the case of digital images chat with me while I work. I plan to have the Live Stream happen once every other week.
  • Any contributor giving $100 or more will receive a 11*18 sized poster of one of the pictures(my choosing) as well as a soft cover book containing all their pictures for their personal enjoyment.
  • Anyone Willing to provide A whopping $1000 contribution, will receiving every prize posted thus far. They will also get to decide on the style and medium of one of the pictures, There will be a page dedicated to the contributors of this level giving them much needed credit and a small section of text to put whatever they want(pg13 please)
  •  Anyone giving $1500 or more, not only will they get everything offered so-far, but they get to keep the original copy of the of the image they decide on, in the case of Digital media the original files will be deleted as to not be re-editable in the future.
  • The last grand-pappy of them all. If any one person gives $2000 or more, the entirety I am trying to raise, I can only offer a paltry prize. For this person gets to choose the picture that becomes the poster that everyone else receives, Also their book will be upgraded to a hardcover.
I cannot think of any reason that this project will be of value to anyone besides myself any and any other Groening fan. But it will be a serious help for someone trying to get their start as a artist. Knowing I can convince people to pay to have me do something like this will be an amazing feeling, that I would never be able to describe, and allow me to grow as a artist and a professional.

Please share this whenever possible, even a single dollar helps in any way.

story:
De VW Fotobus is een oude T1 van Volkswagen met daarin een photobooth. Simpel, maar toch charmant, uniek en vooral handig. Je kan de bus op verschillende soorten evenementen zetten waar al je gasten foto's kunnen laten trekken ter herinnering.


Niet veel, wel duur:

  • Eerst en vooral de prachtige T1 bus. Er is geen overaanbod, dus geduldig afwachten tot de juiste bus ons toelacht! Wat nu het geval is!
Zie hier onze prachtige bus

  • Photobooth-software die zorgt dat alles vlotjes verloopt.
  • Printer(s)

Je ziet ze tegenwoordig overal, de photobooths. Een kotje, ingehuurd door de organisator van een evenement, waar alle gasten gratis foto's kunnen laten trekken ter herinnering.

Photobooths zijn er ondertussen genoeg op de markt, maar voor een gemiddelde prijs van 550 euro voor 3u mag het wel wat meer zijn dan een simpel houten kotje met een fototoestel. Wij combineren een uniek stijlelement, de bus, met de leuke photobooth.


Hier zijn kort de mogelijkheden dat we zullen aanbieden:

  • Mensen gaan in de bus zitten en maken allerlei foto's. (de bus is het kotje)

 

Dit is een zijaanzicht. De foto zal dus getrokken worden van het midden van het busje naar achter. Zo zie je nog de voorste raampjes. Dit is handig als de locatie buiten is. In weer en wind kunnen mensen binnen om foto's te laten trekken.


  • De mensen gaan achter het stuur zitten en hebben een foto van het alombekende hippiebusje (de bus is het decor voor de foto en het evenement)

Dit zal ongeveer het beeld van de foto zijn. Waarschijnlijk zal er nog iets meer ingezoomd worden zodat je de mensen goed achter het stuur ziet zitten. Zo hebben de mensen een foto van zichzelf in het retro-busje.


Wie zijn onze mogelijke klanten:
Simpel, iedereen. Overal waar een auto kan staan, kan de bus staan, ideaal dus voor trouwfeesten, festivals, markten, beurzen, bedrijfsevenementen…
De organisator (evenementenbureau, trouwers…) kunnen ons inhuren zodat de gasten urenlang foto's van zichzelf kunnen laten nemen ter herinnering van de dag.
Het handige is dat je zowel de bus kan personaliseren als de foto's. Je kan je logo op de bus zetten en op de foto's. Als je de foto's dan ook online deelt heb je al heel snel honderden mensen die je logo zien. 
Als je een trouwer ben kan je ipv je logo, de namen van de trouwers of een foto van hun steeds erbij zetten. 
Hieronder wat voorbeelden.

Het startscherm van de ipad dat de gasten zelf kunnen bedienen.


Dit is de layout waar de klanten eventueel zelf de stijl van hun foto kunnen kiezen.

 


Voorbeeld met een logo of tekst


Voorbeeld met een foto van het koppel ipv een logo


Voorbeelden van layouts (niet alleen 3 of 4 onder elkaar, ook een grote met twee kleine foto's, een met 4, een enkele foto...)


En tenslotte een paar extra opties: Foto op facebook, twitter, e-mail, printen…



Perks…
- VW Sleutelhanger


- Koffietas met ons logo


- T-shirts met ons logo (kleuren zijn niet representatief voor de finale druk)


- VW Parking only bord


- Busje op je evenement


Uiteraard zijn er risico's en uitdagingen aan verbonden.

Ten eerste is de aankoop van de bus al een risico. Het zijn dure busjes dat redelijk fragiel zijn. Daarom ga ik al 3 jaar naar VW meetings, rondkijken op fora… om zo in contact te komen met betrouwbare verkopers en enthousiastelingen die mij hun kennis kunnen delen.

Ten tweede de fotostand zelf. Een fotostand is op zich niet moeilijk op te bouwen, maar als het printen en eventueel live online plaatsen van de foto's erbij komt, kan er al snel iets fout gaan. Daarvoor hebben we de hulp ingeschakeld van een productiehuis dat al 7 jaar professioneel bezig is met fotostanden. Zij zullen helpen met de opstart en kunnen ook extra opties aanbieden zoals een extra greenkey-stand waarbij de achtergrond van de foto meteen veranderd kan worden in wat je maar wil.

Ten slotte het onderhoud van de bus. De bus zal van de jaren 70 zijn, maar zal moeten worden gekeurd als een modern voertuig. Omdat het commercieel gebruikt zal worden mag dit niet als oldtimer gekeurd worden. Weer is het dan belangrijk dat het eerste puntje van dit topic zeer goed wordt aangepakt.


Sommige mensen betalen niet graag via internet of zien het nut niet om ons financieel te steunen. Geen paniek, je kan ons ook zeer gemakkelijk helpen door simpelweg: mond aan mondreclame. 

Vertel over ons, onthou onze naam en als er uiteindelijk 1 klant naar ons komt zul je al meer hebben bijgedragen dan wat we hier nu financieel op indiegogo vragen.

story:
The New Lines Alleyway Mural Project

In the summer of 2016, two of Cincinnati's biggest nonprofit names in community revitalization and public art (Keep Cincinnati Beautiful and ArtWorks) are partnering to take their work to Over-the-Rhine's alleyways!

During the months of June-August, 12 new murals will be painted in OTR's Main St. district alleys, which are some of our city's most neglected pedestrian spaces. Led by local Teaching Artists, aided by Apprentices, these murals are designed by artists with local ties. 


The Value of Public Art

By changing the appearance and perception of a neighborhood, public art encourages economic development and improves quality of life at a low cost. 

This project, called New Lines, aims to:

+ mitigate blight in OTR
+ make alleyways more safe, secure, & walkable
+ increase resident buy-in & ownership of neighborhood
+ create must-see spaces for play, performance, & activations
+ implement creative placemaking to enhance historic alleyway system


The Partners

Keep Cincinnati Beautiful (KCB) is a nonprofit organization that decreases litter and blight, promotes sustainability, and cultivates community pride through education and beautification. Its Arts Program uses art as a catalyst for reducing blight, crime, and graffiti in Cincinnati neighborhoods via three methods: enhancing vacant buildings, remediating and beautifying vacant lots, and designing innovative eco-art installations. KCB is an award-winning affiliate of Keep America Beautiful.

ArtWorks is an award-winning non-profit organization that employs and trains local youth and talent to create art and community impact through three strategic programming areas: Public Art, including an extensive mural program; an art therapy division, ArtRx; and an entrepreneurial arm, Creative Enterprise.


How You Can Help

The cost to implement a public art project of this scope is significant. You can help by donating toward the cost.

Keep Cincinnati Beautiful is responsible for fundraising to meet $10,000 of our total commitment toward the project. With a goal of a $5,000 commitment from the local business community and KCB Board, we are seeking a community contribution of $5,000 from friends of KCB and other local residents.

Local business and KCB Board donor commitments, to date, include:

+ Mary Huttlinger, $1,000
+ Amy Lutz, $500

All $25+ donors via this Indiegogo campaign will be invited to the formal Mural Dedication Event in fall of 2016 and we have special perks prepared for higher-level donors, including Keep Cincinnati Beautiful t-shirts, local artist prints, and a private party and alley tour!


Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to donating, you can help bring Keep Cincinnati Beautiful to OTR's alleys by:

+ helping us get the word out about this campaign
+ "share" via social media after you donate


Thank you for helping us bring 12 new murals to OTR by supporting New Lines!

story:
Short Summary

"Intimates" is a photo project by Laurence Philomene (me!)


What I Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • the #1 reason why I made this campaign is to raise some funds to be able to buy colored seamless rolls to use as the backdrop of these images. These are not readily available in montreal in the colors I want (pink, blue, peach, yellow, lavender, etc...) so they need to be ordered in, which adds to the price (about 60-70$ each) so the costs pile up pretty quickly
  • The rest of the funds for this goal will go to other basic studio equipment to set this up (like stands and a reflector) and make sure that I can afford to get this series shot.
  • If I go beyond reaching my goal I will use the rest to fund the project once I am done shooting & editing, for example to print the images, set up an exhibition or even maybe a book out of the images if I reach over 1,000$!!!!!

story:
About Our Campaign

Paper & Blade: Storytelling Under the Knife is the theme that brings four cut paper artists together to engage in an artistic process inspired by cultural and historical phenomenon. Each artist comes from a different ethnic background; national origin and aesthetic style thus bring to the project diversity of beliefs and practices that is the dynamic foundation for this artistic partnership. Their individual practices entail the use of hidden meanings within images and symbols, which will be an interesting point of departure. The artists are fascinated by the ephemeral quality of paper and how it is much like the fleeting experience of human memories/stories and of life itself. 

During February and March 2014, the artists will be in San Francisco engaged in an open art studio at the deYoung’s Kimball Gallery. During these two-months they will be cutting and creating new provocative bodies of work for exhibition at the historic Galeria de la Raza in the cultural and mural rich San Francisco’s Mission District. Starting from four locations in the Galeria the artist’s work will weave towards a central architectural collaboration involving layers of their cut paper works blending together a new narrative. . 

WHAT IS CUT PAPER?  Cut paper is the medium that brings these four artists together, and while each artist has developed their own personalized techniques to obtain their unique styles and aesthetics, the fundamental materials are the same. Meditative in nature, the cutting of paper is a slow, deliberate, and often solitary practice that lends itself to a magical quality.  In order to create with cut paper, the artist must first destroy, an alchemical process, speaking to the divine dichotomy of creation and destruction. 

Why is Paper & Blade: Storytelling Under the Knife worth supporting?

"Paper & Blade" will be a powerful vehicle for communication that cuts across racial, cultural, social, educational and economic barriers and enhances cultural appreciation and awareness. It will be an artistic exploration resulting in visual storytelling, creating a platform for inter-connectivity between the audience and artists. 

How Will Your Support Help Us?

Your generous donation weather big or small will help us reach our fundraising goal - to cover 50% of our travel and lodging cost for two of the artists coming from the East Coast and also help expense the exhibition framing cost. All donations are tax-deductible and will be received and managed by Kua`aina Associates, Inc. (A California based Art & Cultures Non-profit that that is providing the coordination for the artists). 

Artist Ian Kuali`i  

Meet the Artists

Mayumi Hamanaka is a Japanese artist who uses historical photographs and references to examine memory and the mistakes of the past. She uses a subtle process of cutting topographies into photographs, where details start to disappear and amorphous white forms develop like oversize puzzle pieces. Up close they suggest topographical contour maps, but the contours are layers of paper cutouts secured by tiny metal studs. These layers speak to the layers of earth that consists of layers of formerly living things, including humans. http://mayumihamanaka.com/

                                                                                             Invisible Lands - 41" x 58"

Adrienne Heloise researches historical events as the basis for her work and translates early European paintings into contemporary explorations of intimacy, gender and power.   She cuts colored paper, recycled security envelopes and vinyl to recreate images from the French Romantic era paintings.  She delves into the isolation and titillation of homosocial interaction by appropriating the symbols of 19th century western royalty, weaponry and fashion.  http://www.adrienneheloise.com/

                                                                                                     Heartthrob - 10" x 10"

Ian Kuali`i’s creative process is "The meditative process of destroying to create". Blending the contrasting elements of loose graffiti techniques with detailed hand cut paper to manifest unique compositions. His work is a balance between the rough and delicate while exploring ideas of modern progress dependent on a foundation in one’s own history. His art is influenced by his ancestral ties to the Southwest United States and Hawaii, as well as Masonic symbolism, mysticism, global politics and themes of urban decay.http://iankualii.com/

                                                                                             Newarkave and Fragments


Kai Margarida-Ramírez de Arellano was born in Puerto Rico and raised in New Mexico.  This double sense of home has given her a unique perspective on post-colonial, feminist and border identity. Specializing in paper cutting and embroidery, Kai's artwork fuses her family mythology, pop-culture, and intricate handiwork.  Her most recent paper cuts source from family stories and photographs taken by her great-great-grandmother, thereby establishing inter-generational collaborations with her ancestors.  This process has allowed Kai to collapse time and explore her space as a woman between cultures, languages, and epochs. http://www.kaicita.com/

                                                                                                        Floor Tiles Series

Thank-you for Your Gift and for the Supporting the Excellence of the Arts!

For those of you that cannot afford to make a monetary donation, you can still support Paper & Blade: Storytelling Under the Knife by sharing our Indiegogo Campaign with your friends and family via word-of-month, email, and on your social networks.

Kua`aina Associates, Inc. is an art and cultures non-profit that provides support to indigenous arts and cultural organizations and artists by supporting projects that provide opportunities for emerging artists and cultural masters in both traditional and contemporary forms through program development, program management and special projects. Kua`aina’s role with “Paper & Blade” Storytelling Under the Knife is to provide support, coordination and management to the artist fellows during their artistic collaboration.   http://kuaainaassociates.com/
story_txt:
About Our Campaign
Paper & Blade: Storytelling Under the Knife is the theme that brings four cut
paper artists together to engage in an artistic process inspired by cultural
and historical phenomenon. Each artist comes from a
different ethnic background; national origin and aesthetic style thus bring to
the project diversity of beliefs and practices that is the dynamic foundation
for this artistic partnership. Their individual practices entail the use of
hidden meanings within images and symbols, which will be an interesting point
of departure. The artists are fascinated by the ephemeral quality of
paper and how it is much like the fleeting experience of human memories/stories
and of life itself. 
During February and March 2014, the
artists will be in San Francisco engaged in an open art studio at the deYoung’s
Kimball Gallery. During these two-months they will be cutting and creating new
provocative bodies of work for exhibition at the historic Galeria de la Raza in
the cultural and mural rich San Francisco’s Mission District. Starting from
four locations in the Galeria the artist’s work will weave towards a central
architectural collaboration involving layers of their cut paper works blending
together a new narrative. . 
WHAT
IS CUT PAPER?  Cut paper is the medium that brings these four artists together, and
while each artist has developed their own personalized techniques to obtain
their unique styles and aesthetics, the fundamental materials are the same.
Meditative in nature, the cutting of paper is
a slow, deliberate, and often solitary practice that lends itself to a magical
quality.  In order to create with cut paper, the artist must first
destroy, an alchemical process, speaking to the divine dichotomy of creation
and destruction. 
Why is Paper & Blade: Storytelling Under the Knife worth supporting?"Paper & Blade" will be a powerful vehicle for communication that cuts across racial, cultural, social, educational and economic barriers and enhances cultural appreciation and awareness. It will be an artistic exploration resulting in visual storytelling, creating a platform for inter-connectivity between the audience and artists. How Will Your Support Help Us?
Your generous
donation weather big or small will help us reach our fundraising goal - to
cover 50% of our travel and lodging cost for two of the artists coming from the
East Coast and also help expense the exhibition framing cost. All donations
are tax-deductible and will be received and managed by Kua`aina Associates,
Inc. (A California based Art & Cultures Non-profit that that is providing
the coordination for the artists). 
Artist Ian
Kuali`i  Meet the Artists
Mayumi Hamanaka is
a Japanese artist who uses
historical photographs and references to examine memory and the mistakes of the
past. She uses a subtle process of cutting topographies into photographs, where
details start to disappear and amorphous white forms develop like oversize
puzzle pieces. Up close they suggest topographical contour maps, but the
contours are layers of paper cutouts secured by tiny metal studs. These layers
speak to the layers of earth that consists of layers of formerly living
things, including humans. http://mayumihamanaka.com/                                                                                             Invisible Lands - 41" x 58"
Adrienne
Heloise researches historical events as the basis for her work
and translates early European paintings into contemporary explorations of
intimacy, gender and power.   She cuts colored paper, recycled
security envelopes and vinyl to recreate images from the French Romantic era
paintings.  She delves into the isolation and titillation of homosocial
interaction by appropriating the symbols of 19th century western royalty,
weaponry and fashion.  http://www.adrienneheloise.com/                                                                                                     Heartthrob - 10" x 10"Ian Kuali`i’s creative process is "The meditative process of destroying
to create". Blending the contrasting elements of loose graffiti techniques
with detailed hand cut paper to manifest unique compositions. His work is a
balance between the rough and delicate while exploring ideas of modern progress
dependent on a foundation in one’s own history. His art is influenced by his
ancestral ties to the Southwest United States and Hawaii, as well as Masonic
symbolism, mysticism, global politics and themes of urban decay.http://iankualii.com/                                                                                             Newarkave and Fragments
Kai
Margarida-Ramírez de Arellano
was born in Puerto Rico and raised
in New Mexico.  This double sense of home has given her a unique
perspective on post-colonial, feminist and border identity. Specializing in
paper cutting and embroidery, Kai's artwork fuses her family mythology,
pop-culture, and intricate handiwork.  Her most recent paper cuts source
from family stories and photographs taken by her great-great-grandmother,
thereby establishing inter-generational collaborations with her ancestors.
 This process has allowed Kai to collapse time and explore her space as a
woman between cultures, languages, and epochs. http://www.kaicita.com/


                                                                                                        Floor Tiles Series

afford to make a monetary donation, you can still support Paper & Blade: Storytelling Under the Knife by sharing our Indiegogo Campaign with your
friends and family via word-of-month, email, and on your social networks.

indigenous arts and cultural organizations and artists by supporting projects
that provide opportunities for emerging artists and cultural masters in both

Storytelling Under the Knife is to provide
support, coordination and management to the artist fellows during their
artistic collaboration.   http://kuaainaassociates.com/

story:
Our Story

The indiExhibit is a small, but growing, group of artists,indie crafters, and jewelers from around the world. Together we contribute our work to some of the hottest Hollywood event gift lounges to promote not only ourselves, but each other as well. The indiExhibit is made up of very talented people that brainstorm regularly to make the group grow and become better with each show. We have recently opened up our group to other artists that are committed to taking their work to a higher level.

Our members currently split the cost of the participation fee with each show, which, once added with the cost of product and materials for the individual gifts for the swag bags, can still be rather pricey. Not only do our members come from around the globe, but also from different walks of life. Some of our members are disabled. Some of them are starving artists out of work. Some of them are mothers and fathers with one income families. Because of these financial issues, there are more than just a few of our most talented members
who cannot participate in these events due to the costs.

Unfortunately, art is one of the first programs to go when schools and neighborhoods are looking to cut costs. Not everyone sees the importance of the individual artist, especially those who are struggling to establish themselves in today's economy.

The goal at The indiExhibit is to raise enough funds so that ALL of our members will be able to participate in the gift lounge(s) of their choice without the stress of splitting the participation fee, and eventually, with enough donations to be able to finance part or all of the costs for materials as well. We believe that every artist, crafter and indie designer should be able to participate in these shows, regardless of their income.

The Impact

The indiExhibit is more than just a group of artists who show off their wares in Hollywood. We are a close knit community who truly cares about each other and how to help every artist in the group become the best that they can be. The indiExhibit members are friends. We are family. We are a support group. Participating in these gift lounges not only promotes each individual member of the group, but also encourages their creativity and pushes them to do better with each show. The indiExhibit helps artists find and have faith in themselves.


What We Need & What You Get

The breakdown of cost for the Kids Choice Award Gift Lounge are as follows:


$5000 for the participation fee

$  500 for lodging during the event

$  400 for airfare for one representative (round trip)

$  300 for gas for second representative (round trip)


We found the Indie Go Go site a bit late in the game, so we have part of the funds already. As of right now, the lodging, air fare and gas is covered. With The indiExhibit being such a tight knit group, the members themselves have come together to donate perks to help raise funds :)


If funds are not raised, it will mean a ton of out of pocket costs to our members, which of course we will pull together one way or another, but any fund raising that we can get will help :)


Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to help, but are feeling the stain on your own pocketbook, NO WORRIES! The Indie Go Go site has a ton of share tools for you to share this campaign with friends and family on Twitter, Facebook, MySpace and more! You can also feel free to contact the indiExhibit founder, Shannon Justice (that would be me) at info@theindiexhibit.org for any questions :)


Thank you so much for taking the time to read through this! It means the world to each of our 208 members!

Have a wonderful day and keep on creating!



Perks can be seen on our webpage: http://www.theindiexhibit.org/FundRaiserPerks


Shannon Justice

founder of The indiExhibit

story:
The Maneki Neko or "Beckoning Cat" is an auspicious good luck symbol originating from Japan during the Edo Period, and is still prevalent today. It is said to bring good luck and prosperity to home, family, friends, and business. A Lucky Cat myself, I've been inspired by their beauty and decided to sketch them one day. I've made many art trading cards in the past so decided to turn my final sketches into just that. But then I didn't draw just one...I kept drawing and made more...And More...AND MORE! Obsession! I designed many many cards, but was sad at the thought of giving them away individually. Nobody would ever see the full series. SADNESS! But then I had another idea...put all the kitties  into a mini book so everyone can enjoy the happinesses of lucky cats! So even those people not lucky enough to be owned by a cat may still find the joys of their elegance in art. Sweetness!

In the legends, the Maneki Neko originally was a Japanese calico bobtail cat...that means a multi-spotted cat with a nub for a tail. Don't laugh! There are several stories about how the legend began but one of the most widely believed versions involves a cat and his monk. The cat was sitting in the doorway of the monk's temple during a terrible storm, and a samurai or nobleman took shelter nearby under a tree. As the story goes, the nobleman saw the cat "waving" to him, and so he went to the temple for better shelter, an act that saved his life since lightning struck the tree seconds after! Thankful, he gave the monk much wealth, which the monk in turn gave back to his community. Word traveled about this cat and soon business owners carved cats to put in their shops, and people bought them to put in doorways of their homes...all hoping the lucky cat would bring them prosperity.

Today, the iconic cat is still seen in some shops and homes, often painted gold. They can be holding various symbolic objects like the koban (gold coin), a fish, ingot (boat-shaped gold piece), goard, crystal ball, money mallet, and more. Some come in other colors which also have meanings (although many meanings differ), and some kitties show a right paw raised (good luck and wealth), while others have the left paw raised (inviting company and customers), while others still wave both paws (protecting family and home). Many lucky cats don't have tails, while others do, and many have a collar, bell, and bib. It is considered very feng shui to place a Maneki Neko facing an entrance to your home or business.

I Can Has Lucky Cat Arts?

This book compiles all of my current series of Maneki Nekos into one place, totaling currently at 27 images. No one has to miss a cat! HAPPINESS! There's a variety of kitties, with background colors of the rainbow. The book is also sized so you'll be seeing the art at true scale...the size it was created at and originally intended to be (art cards are standardly sized at 2.5X3.5" like a playing card). Plus, it fits in your pocket and can go anywhere, giving you a smile and good feelings whenever you take a peek in. Also, it's glossy and hairball free, like me! However, please note the book is more an art project than a publishing venture right now, so if you really want a copy pledge now before it eludes you! Don't be a sad kitty! Even if the goal for this project is NOT met, you WILL get the reward you pledged for!

BACKER REWARDS! 

THE POCKET MANEKI NEKO BOOK: This is what it's all about, my lovelies! A small book just slightly larger than an ATC itself (aprox. 3.75x2.5"), containing all 27 images of the Maneki Neko project. All books will come with an original Maneki Neko sketch on the inside cover, are signed, and numbered!

COLORING PAGE: Everyone that pledges will get a free black and white coloring page for the kittens in their lives to color. This is sent digitally so you can print as many copies as you need for your litter.

ATCs: Everyone that pledges deserves a lucky cat! My Maneki Nekos were originally designed as cards, so it makes the most sense that everyone have at least one in its original format. You'll get to choose which card you'd like to have**. Those that get the printed edition ATCs shipped will also get the art signed, soft-sleeved, & sleeved into a durable top-loader suitable for display all on its own. Prints are matte finished.

5X7" PRINTS: ATCs with a black & colored border to imitate a mat for very nice framing. You get to pick the ATC** and the color "mat" border to best match your home or office. Printed versions also come signed and have a matte finish.

BOOKMARKS: Bookmarks only come printed. Hopefully they will be on heavy UV glossy bookmark paper - this is in the works, and with a tassle if I can help it. I love batting at tassles! These bookmark prints will be of the design I am drawing up as seen in the video.

ORIGINAL ATCs FROM THE BOOK: Originals come signed, soft-sleeved, & sleeved into a durable top-loader. Sorry, but choices for these are randomly shipped. However, you can tell me 2-3 favorite colors or images** and I will try my best to get you one of those cards...but no promises my lovelies! But that's not all! I'll also throw in a little black plastic stand so you can display the original card anywhere! Classy! All these kitty cards need good homes. Original art cards come with the most beautiful lucky cat golden envelopes too, yes.

**NOTE: At the end of the campaign you will be shown all of the cards from the book in order to pick which you'd like to have.

 

*EVEN IF THE PROJECT GOAL ISN'T MET, YOU WILL STILL GET YOUR REWARD PERKS! And yes, you CAN use PayPal!*

story:
Who We are

 Longmont Council for the Arts believes art enhances the quality of life. Every day, we inspire creativity for our artists, students and patrons because art e.nables us to see the world in a different way. Since 1985 we have been working to enhance the arts in Longmont for the community and support our artists so they can be artists. As part of the Longmont Arts & Entertainment District, we are working to unify, enhance and promote the arts within downtown.

Vision

This project of blank breezeway walls inspired both artists and organizations to make a creative statement of the impact of the arts in Longmont. By bringing together a group of local artists with the Longmont Council for the Arts and the Longmont Downtown Development Authority to brainstorm possible artistic additions to the breezeway and the entire downtown district the concept of an outdoor art gallery emerged. This outdoor gallery will be a mix of the dynamic and enduring, the past and the future.  The top portion of the walls will be its focal point, featuring a permanent mural by Gamma Acosta telling Longmont's Story.  Artist Cynthia Marsh will collaborate with Gamma to create 3-D figures on the lower part of the wall that will draw people in to the Breezeway.

Why we need you help

We have been offered a matching grant of $5,000 once we raise $5,000.  We are well on our way and need $1,500 to help bring us to that goal.

It has been very exciting to see this project develop and our great artists who helped design it. The money raised will help pay a portion of the artist stipend to create the mural.

Longmont's Story

The Community -past, present & future - is the inspiration for the mural.  To tell Longmont's Story through the eyes of the artists. The people, places and quirky stories that make our town and its history memorable.  Art is important to a community’s identity and quality of life.  By creating a permanent outdoor gallery, we are providing more opportunities for our artists to increase their stability and enhance our community.
